description: The very good Thai restaurant in Castro area. The girl who took order for us was very friendly. I love their curry in the real bumpkin bowl, it' taste is awesome.
author: Nguyen S.

description:
Decent Thai restaurant in Castro.

My company had the Monday off for California Admissions Day.
Since I was very behind on homework, I decided to spend a study day in the City.
Wanting Thai food, but not knowing where to go, I stumbled across Thailand Restaurant's sign that said they offered lunch specials, Monday through Friday's from noon to 3PM.

After looking through their menu, I decided to get a 2 entrée lunch special, with (Chicken) Pad Kra Pow and (Chicken) Panang Curry, that came with a side of rice and a salad. The combination was $12.95 before tax and tip, which I felt was fair for San Francisco/Castro prices.

The food was alright; it seemed like the red peppers in the Pad Kra Pow were more for appearances rather than heat. The Panang Curry was good but wasn't as full-bodied as I would like for a curry.

Overall, it was a good spot to satisfy my thai-cravings and hunger.
author: Kevin W.

description: This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the Castro ( I've been to three) lovely service and very authentic flavors. I lived in Thailand for 18 months and this takes me back! Fresh and complex. Great for vegetarians.
author: Nils H.

description:
Thai food done right. Green curry with shrimp was just incredible. Nicely hot (spicewise) and so much prawn. 

Pad See Ew my husband had was similarly delicious, just so damn heart warming. Rice was even perfect. 

Service was awesome, the ambiance was nice (except for a self-absorbed man that talked non-stop at his companion for an hour straight after they'd finished their meal, which of course wasn't Thailand's fault!!) and they even had beautiful Christmas decorations up, which we loved. 

I am hardly ever in the Castro but I'm planning my next trip there just so I can happen to mention 'why don't we slide on up to Thailand restaurant'. Oh yes, this restaurant has no shop front and is up a flight of stairs so many sure you don't miss it! 

Thank you Thailand! Your food was so, so, so good!
author: Zoe L.

description:
Came here for a quick bite after workout. We came at 8 PM on Saturday so beat the rush and were able to get seated by the window. I didn't mind the ambiance, you walk up a flight of stairs and are seated quickly. I wasn't that turned off by the decor and layout - there's a random fireplace in the middle of the restaurant like it was someone's living room. Food is your run of the mill Thai, mild, inoffensive, albeit a little bland and too sweet. The spicy level was still subdued.

Angel Wings - breaded and sliced, stuffed with glass noodle. Tender enough meat, though breading was grainy resembled that of frozen chicken nuggets.
Tasty Eggplant - Texture was between mushy and firm, it didn't turn into a puree but not bad.
Cashew Nut Chicken - A little on the sweet side but nicely seasoned, meat was a little rubbery.

It wouldn't be my first choice for Thai food in the area with other places nearby but not half bad.
author: Truc N.

description: Quick, efficient, and affordable. I normally place my order over the telephone for pick up. They're always on time and I definitely recommend this place for a quick casual meal. :)
author: Wesley F.

description:
On the expensive side for what you get.

Delivery took over an hour and the food was cold. It may be a better experience in the restaurant but I was not happy with the delivery, also I ordered a $2 vegetable upgrade on the shrimp dish and they sent me a bit of steamed carrot. I was completely unsatisfied.
author: Manny F.

description:
It had been years since I'd popped in here... I have a friend who is friendly with the servers at both of the other nearby Thai restaurants (Thai House Express and Thai Chef), so he always chooses our location... but last night I was solo and nearby and hungry, so why not...

Greeted promptly, seated by the window with a really cute view of the street, passersby. The panang curry and the papaya salad I ordered were quite good, maybe not exceptional in a way that blows away all others, but certainly hit the spot, and the prices were reasonable/standard.

Certainly a good option, worthy of rotating into the mix of places to grab Thai food in the Castro.
author: Sean B.

description:
I've been here in the past and it's been better. 
We ordered Chicken Praram and Pad Thai dishes. Both arrived very quickly, which was nice. But they both seemed kind of bland and lacked flavor. 

Two different servers waited on us.  The first person was a guy who just walked up and stood by the table. We assumed he was there like he was ready to take our order... but he didn't say hello, or smile or anything.  He just stood there.  It was odd.  We said "hello", but he didn't really respond.  So we eventually assumed he just wanted us to order and so we did.

Being a polite, well mannered person myself, I always wonder what is going on.  Are they having a terrible day?  Do they hate their job?  Do they hate customers?  Do they have a migraine? One will never know. 

The second person who served us was very friendly, polite and upbeat.  That was nice and helped to make up for the first person who was just kind of flat. 

All in all, it was a middle of the road restaurant experience.
author: Rob O.

description: Good food but it can be a bit slow on the service but with good food and I think it expected when going to a Thai restaurant. Always try the appetizers course it's one way to sample a bit of what they have to offer.
author: RICHARD J.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but everything about it was subpar.

Let's begin with the setup of the restaurant. You walk up the staircase which the restaurant doors leads you to. Once at the top of the staircase, it's as if you've entered someone's living room. Huge bay windows, a fireplace, odd wall decor that doesn't match with the cloth napkin decorated tables. An unusual vibe for a restaurant, and a Thai restaurant at that. 

Once seated, I decided to go with the Raad Na Pak (Pan fried flat noodles with tofu, broccoli and a light gravy sauce). I love them wide flat noodles and broccoli-- what could go wrong? A lot, friends, a lot. Notice they say "light gravy sauce"-- this sauce was anything but light. When I received my dish, it was as if I ordered a noodle soup. My noodles, broccoli, and tofu were swimming in this thin gravy. Being open minded, I decided to go ahead and taste what I was served. Unfortunately, the story doesn't get any better, friends. My dish lacked any type of flavor; it was the plainest noodle dish you could imagine. I doused my dish with chili so I could taste something. I left feeling sad, guys, sad because the Thai food I received at this restaurant did not remotely accurately represent what real Thai food is: bursts of flavor, spices, and color. 

I will say the service wasn't terrible. The servers were polite, and that is Thailand Restaurant's saving grace.

If you're in the Castro, seek elsewhere for food, friends.
author: Nicole A.

description: Finally I decided to try this place ever since walking pass their door every week for the past 3 years. We tried their Tom Yum Goong, Spicy Seafood and Roasted Duck dish. Unfortunately this place is not the place to go for those looking for Authentic Thai. All the dishes are not spicy at all and taste like sautéed meat with sweet and sour sauce. Service is minimal. Price is astronomically high whereas you can get much better Thai elsewhere in nearby area.
author: Richard W.

description: Very Good restaurant  Thailand restaurant  best of the best if you want to looking restaurant  you can go this Thailand restaurant
author: Tony T.

description: Awesome place! My to go spot for Thai food. Prices are reasonable. Tasty food! $12  for a chicken noodle curry.
author: Ibelig V.

description:
It was one of those nights where festivities is during the day and your all just exhausted for food and more drinks. 
.
This is where we ended up at. So we got sat down and just ordered away. 
.
Btw there is a stair case to go up to the restaurant. So might be tricky or hidden. But big sign to not mislead where your going upstairs. 
.
Thai coconut seafood soup -this was yummy. Soothing for the throat. The fresh ingredients inside was nummy. Love the fresh shrimp and mushrooms! Very good to start with. 
.
Papaya salad - thai style. It was sweet and spicy. Looked refreshing. This wasn't as spicy as i thought it would be. But it was good because i was craving this. Beautifully presented with lots of color. Light and refreshing, and opens the palette for a more appetizing meal. 
.
Bbq beef - savory. Sweet. Full of flavors. Tender beef. Juicy but yet satisfying. Pairs well with rice for sure. 
.
Cashew chicken - lots of chicken with scattered cashew on random bites. Juicy saucy and unique flavor from this dish. Easily one of my to go to dish on any day. 
. 
Stir fry pineapple duck - smokey roasted duck in full flavor. Love the pineapple sweet sauce to compliment it. As well goes good with some carb white rice. Just love how the duck has its own flavor even when smuttered with their signature sauce. 
. 
Stir fry thai basil seafood - basically the basil in the sauce is what compliments this dish. Love the fresh seafood used in this dish. Love the big size shrimps! Nice and light dish. 
.
Bottle of merlot - compliments the seafood and bbq beef for sure. As well calms the spiciness down too. 
.
Brown rice - filler food but just goes so damn good with all the dishes named above. At least they offer brown rice okayyyy.
.
Overall chat about the festivities. Eat a little bit, drink some more. Calling it a night in Castro is what's up. Thanks for reading and stay classy. With a little bit of sassss. Lol have a yelptastic day! 
.
author: Alex T.

description: Good restaurant. The red curry with duck was good. It's above some 440 club, so you can hear the music from the club vibrating through the room.
author: Lyndsey G.

description: A Castro must stop.  The spring rolls (non fried) are wonderful.  The green curry is delicious.  I have also enjoyed the red curry with pumpkin.  You can order on eat24 to have it delivered.  It's almost enough to share 1 dish.
author: Joe Q.

description:
Great food.  Perfect location.
Ask for a table by the window overlooking the Castro theater.
author: Michael S.

description:
I don't know what took Jamie W. and me so long to try this place. After all, we like Thai food, and we pass by it every time we're on Castro, or at least we pass by the sign since you can't really see the restaurant from street level. It's upstairs on the second floor of a Victorian where the windows face the neon marquee of the Castro Theater (photo: http://bit.ly/1bQis8o). There are also two other so-so Thai places in the Castro where you don't have to climb stairs to get to them. Maybe we've concluded so-so Thai is better than a potential groin injury on those stairs. Now I'm just making up excuses, but we finally made it.

Yes, we tried Thailand, and I have to say that satisfying Thai food continues to be an elusive search in the Castro. We started on a misstep because we didn't read the descriptions carefully enough. We thought we ordered true Spring Rolls when we asked for the $6.95 Thailand Rolls, but it turned out to be fried ones, and it turned out to be two dollars extra for "Fresh" Spring Rolls. Even though they were decent enough, it was a bummer since I didn't want to have an oily crunch in my mouth when I wasn't prepared for it (photo: http://bit.ly/1yDshLN).  Jamie was more forgiving, and he segued into the $8.95 Chicken Noodles.

It was a rather bland plate of pan-fried noodles sauteed with chicken, egg, bean sprouts, onions and ground peanuts (photo: http://bit.ly/1GNZHOX). I decided to get into a more vegetarian mode with the $8.50 Pad Ma Keau, a full plate of sauteed eggplant mixed in black bean sauce, garlic and basil (photo: http://bit.ly/1CzIaXI). It was tasty enough for me but still lacked a certain oomph to make it completely winning. Weak menu choices? Perhaps but even a base hit among the three dishes would have been nice. Couple that with the rather passive service, and it made for an evening infused with a pervasive mehness despite the passing quality of the food that was served. So down the stairs we go.

FOOD - 3 stars...middling Thai dishes make the journey to the top of the stairs a fitful one
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...a bit like someone's living room converted to a restaurant, for better or worse
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...not sure if they were trying to be unobtrusive but it came across as a bit passive
TOTAL - 3 stars...don't expect a stairway to heaven
author: Ed U.

description:
The service was excellent, but not enough to pull in the ratings for quality of the food. 
The duck curry was soupy not creamy and lacked flavor.
The stuffed chicken wings had same foamy texture as chicken nuggets.
Cute place to convert a residential flat into a restaurant, but I would not come back.
author: Dee G.

description: I'm not sure why Thailand Restaurant doesn't have higher ratings! It has a nice atmosphere, sweet and attentive staff, and, most importantly, fantastic food. I ordered the poh taag, which I absolutely loved and definitely recommend.
author: Katherine N.

description:
Came here for an early dinner on a Sunday night.  Street parking is basically impossible.  The restaurant is up a stairwell in what used to be a residence.  Not a large restaurant.  Service was fine.  

We had five dishes.  I especially enjoyed the pad thai and the roast duck.  The fresh spring rolls were good too.  The mango dessert was just OK.  

I'd eat here again.  Just watch out for the single step up to the restroom and another step up to the toilet itself.  Gets tricky when you are leaving the restroom!
author: Doctor G.

description: Nice, casual restaurant with super friendly service.  I was there just last week with a friend and we both enjoyed our meal.  I wasn't that hungry and was going to order an appetizer, and the waitress talked me into another; the angel wings.  They were stuffed with noodles and other things and had a nice presentation and were nice and crispy as well as flavorful.  I'm glad she recommended them.  Super friendly service.  I actually give this place 3 1/2 stars.
author: Delicious B.

description:
We were driving near the Castro looking for a quick bite and randomly found this Thai restaurant tucked between a bar and a store.   What a great discovery, the place provides a great view of Castro street (choose a window side table) and a great lunch special. 

The restaurant is located upstairs, which adds this feeling that you are stepping into someone's home.  The decor is nice and clean.  We ordered off the lunch special menu, that includes a list of one item combinations or pick two combinations.  The two item plates include salad, but all lunch specials include soup.

The soup was sour deliciousness in a small bowl that left me very happy. The green curry was also very good, but surprisingly did not have eggplant.  This was the first time ever having green curry w/o eggplant, but it was good nonetheless.  

Its hard for me not give this place 4 stars for the value and the view of the Castro alone.  Tasty food w a view always makes my day, maybe you should try the curry w a view ^_^
author: Marlon T.

description: Authentic Thai food? Here is it is!! I am in love!! Thai papaya salad, BBQ pork, mango salad, phat Thai, pat seeyew(flat tummy noodles), silver noodles!!
author: Serenade K.

description: Giving this place a 3 cause the Bbq pork was good . It's just crazy that it didn't come with rice . The plate was already 11.99 plus $2 for rice and on top of all that our waitress was rude! Won't be returning . Lucky Thai house in Berkeley is way better plus hella cheaper. Your welcome .
author: Chazmin F.

description: Excellent. Generous portions, great flavor, nice presentation. I highly recommend. And they have fish sauce with Thai chiles as a condiment. Yum! Waitstaff is super as well.
author: Paul P.

description:
We had 5 in our party. Food was ok, smaller servings. We ordered two types of soft shell crab for three of us, the other two ordered chicken and pork dishes, because they don't eat fish.  They delivered the softshell crab, and then over 20 minutes later deliver the rest of the food.  Three we're done eating before the other food was delivered. Of course the three that had eaten were bored so they snacked on our dishes, we didn't get much food.  

The bill came to about $110, on top of that, they automatically added a 20% tip. If it's mandatory it's not a tip, it's part of the cost of the food. We were not a party of 12, we were only a party of five, and the service was bad. We will not return to this restaurant.
author: Mike K.

description:
In terms of things on the menu, it's your typical Thai restaurant, nothing too amazing. Reasonably priced lunch specials.
Came in for dinner once and the waitress didn't let us know that rice costs extra on my yellow curry dish when asking if I wanted rice with it. Not impressed.
author: Elisa L.

description:
I am going to keep it simple; DISGUSTING!

No wonder this place was half empty when I came in.
author: Allan S.

description: Employees were nice, but food was salty to the point that I couldn't eat it. It also gets so noisy that you can't hear anything people are saying. Take a critical look at your food quality and you can boost your score.
author: Dan D.

description: Flavor: 3.5 Panang Curry with Shrimp. Ordered Egg Fried Rice as a side. You can choose between brown rice, jasmine rice and egg fried rice. 132 Linda vista dr
author: Alex Z.

description: Location, location, location .....that's all the reason I feel this restaurant is surviving with its below average food, terrible server and slow unfriendly service in a city that's famous for it's great restaurants all around. It's located right across Castro Theater, so out of convenience we walked into it on Halloween night. The Hostess was nice and got us a table by the window in no time. The place wasn't busy at all at 9 pm. Then comes the disappointment.....took forever to show up to take order in non-peak hour. We ordered Pad Prik w beef and Pad Khing with chicken. Despite asking to make it highest level of hot flavor, dishes were extremely sweet, almost inedible. Whenever we asked for something, like chopsticks and hot sauce, the server looked extremely surprised and had a very unwilling to serve attitude. To top it off, half way through my dinner, he took the hot sauce caddie and gave it to the people at the next table. Terrible ending of a fun Halloween night at Castro. Definitely won't be back.
author: Ash A.

description: Really exceptional chicken satay and drunk noodles. Owner was extremely friendly and the restaurant and bathrooms were clean. Will definitely be back if ever in the area again.
author: Dustin S.

description:
A few of my friends from HS were visiting from Vegas the other day, and we were walking around the Castro and happened to stumble upon this place. It was easy, looked decent, and we decided "what the hell" and went for it. 

The place very visibly a converted apartment turned into a restaurant. Narrow stairs up to the restaurant, small, low ceilings, looks like you're sitting in someones living room. I thought it was adorable, but my friends from Vegas (used to wide sprawling spaces) were so confused. 

Even though the restaurant wasn't necessarily busy, it took them a while to send a server our way. I noticed after about 10 minutes without water or a hello something was up, so I waved one down. No one wants to wave down a server.. 

All of us got the pad thai (so safe, I know). I got a glass of red wine, and they stuck with waters. The Pad Thai was.. fine. Just fine. Not great, not bad, we ate it because we were hungry, but I probably wouldn't order again. My wine was mediocre as well -- I'm not expecting a groundbreaking glass of wine from this Castro thai restaurant, though. 

All in all, pretty okay experience. Probably won't be coming back since I've had much better Thai in the city.
author: Alex G.

description: I ordered egg noodles with chicken. It was disgusting. Chicken was raw. You better do your work better guys.
author: Vladimir E.

description:
the Good: the Gaw Praw Duck was amazing: perfect char, but still super moist. Very flavorful.

the Bad: They charge an extra $2 for rice & $2.50 for brown rice. the service was not that great (they tried, but they weren't very good), and there was a really weird smell when you first walk in that is pretty unappetizing.

Five star for the food, minus two for the Bad.
author: Sam J.

description:
The food is absolutely amazing, some of the best Thai food I've had. The waiter was rude to us the whole time and then charged us all for a 20% tip!! When we tried adding to our order he snapped "Hold on" and said he had to come back because our table was difficult for him to handle. Lol, awesome food and I'll gladly come back, but hopefully without that waiter (man with tattoo under his left ear)

UPDATE: the waiter came up to us as we were leaving and yelled at us when he heard us talking about how the 20% tip was unfair trying to start something!!
author: Grady C.

description:
Bottom Line: Very rude service with a lot of attitude and highly unprofessional staff. This review is written by a former restaurant server and host.

I was a server and a host for a year at a restaurant and I know really bad service when I see it. I stopped here with my friend after a yoga class. It was about 9:40 and they close at 10. It was her birthday and I was really excited to take her out. As soon as we got there, the host said abruptly we could only order take out and we couldn't eat there since the restaurant is closing.

From experience, usually you do allow guests to still seat 20 minutes before closing and if you can't, then you usually say something like, "Hi guys, we're really sorry but the best we can do is provide take out because the restaurant is closing soon. Is this okay with you?" We decided to do takeout anyway. Strike 1.

Five minutes into looking at the menu, the host then says, "I don't want to be rude but the kitchen is closing soon so you need to order!" Again, a better approach might be, "Hi guys, our kitchen is closing soon and I want to get your order in before it does. I have some great recommendations if you are having trouble deciding. Is there anything I can help with?" Strike 2.

We rush our order and I hand the host my American Express. He glances at it haughtily, hands it back and says, we don't take American Express. Do you have something else. Exasperated by my whole experience in the course of 5 minutes, I replied this is kind of ridiculous. He looked up, glared at me said you have a bad attitude. He cancels our order and then kicks us out of the restaurant making snide remarks as we leave.

Look, I know the restaurant industry is stressful - I've lived it. But there's something really wrong when a restaurant allows its host to be that rude and give that much attitude. This is restaurant earns a well-deserved 1 star.
author: Eric N.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in the Castro. Good food and good service. Great view of Castro Theater from the window seats.
author: Martin N.

description:
About the place: upstairs in an old house. No bar and not a lot of room to wait for a table BUT staff is super nice and you can order drinks in line. 

About the food: good but not amazing. Spring rolls, yellow curry chicken, and pad Thai. We asked for extra peanut sauce and they gave us a ton. YUM. Plates are good for sharing :) Standard Thai with lots of variety. Again review is not negative I will definitely go back, but it is sort of standard. We went Halloween night and didn't have to wait too long. 

About the staff: super nice...great customer service!!
author: Neal B.

description:
We started with the chicken satay and both thought that their peanut sauce was one of the better ones that we've had,  The accompanying cucumber salad was nicely seasoned too and did not overwhelm the dish with too much vinegar.  Rather, it brightened and separated the two different flavors presented on this appetizer.

The Chicken Noodles were pan fried flat noodles with chicken, egg, bean sprouts, onions, and ground peanuts.  This is not a spicy dish but again, the flavors were totally present and unique.  

We also shared the most popular Goong Pea Seau (Butterfly Prawns).  They are prawns, stuffed with crab meat, marinated in garlic and pepper, rolled in batter; served on a bed of cabbage and served with sweet and sour and spicy sauce.
I asked for brown rice with this dish.  There were 5 pieces of battered shrimp to share.  The sweet and sour sauce and the spicy sauce were nice choices to add on top of each piece.  The prawns themselves were moist and delicious.

You're going here for the food--not the ambiance or decor.  It's kind of a funky place with steep steps that you must ascend before entering the dining room.  Some walls are painted a deep red and other walls are white with small, halved, ping-pong looking things sticking out and adding texture.  Again, you're going here for the food...
author: Thomas D.

description:
Whenever I think of Thai I realy think of 4 places and this is one of them.  

This is my go to if I want some Chicken Pra Ram (Chicken & Spinich with Peanut Sauce).  The peanut sauce is what makes the dish and this is probably one of the better ones I've had in the city because it's very peanut buttery.
author: Spencer Q.

description: Tried the crab pad Thai-- three pieces of crab meat.. Nothing zomg crazy delish but fair to what I ordered. Partner tried the pumpkin seafood curry, which looked quite ornate. The food is pretty decent-okay-- I like going here for the relatively calm atmosphere though. I could either look out into the Castro streets, or into my partners eyes as romancy koit-Esque songs play.
author: Alexander T.

description: Best pad thai I've had in the Bay Area!!!! Reminds me of the way they make it in Southern California! Divine!
author: Christine S.

description:
Thailand Restaurant is good in a pinch - if that pinch is "Hey, I'm down on Castro for a film and I want a bite to eat - quick!"

As other reviewers have mentioned, despite the sign declaiming vegetarian cuisine, they aren't more veg-friendly here than any other thai restaurant at the Bay Area.  In fact, I might caution you:  they are not entirely vegetarian aware, so be absolutely sure to ask the server if there is fish sauce (Nam Pla) in the vegetable/vegetarian dish you are about to order.  If the server seems hesitant, smile gently and ask them to go confirm it with the chef... 

That said, it's your basic Bay Area thai food, pretty solid with all the usual sorts of things - and a pretty good value for your buck.  The dining room is pretty nice - on a second floor so you get a good view of people watching down on the street.

If you are vegetarian - just be sure to ask about the menu.  And remember - lots of people in other countries consider fish a vegetable (in Mexico, they think vegetarians eat chicken and only "strict" vegetarians do not).
author: Jenn C.

description: The food really was inedible; I'm sorry to say! I was the only one in the restaurant at lunch time in a busy part of the Castro--which should have been a strong indicator not to eat here--but we all make mistakes. I left more than half my food on my plate-- the vegetables in the curry were literally frozen cubes of carrots and frozen peas.
author: Reena R.

description:
Every time I go here, I am never disappointed.  I've been coming here for over a decade, because I Live in the neighborhood.  I have multiple options for different Thai places, but this spot is always my go-to! 

They deliver, they're fast and the price is right for the portions. 

My favorites:
Tom Ka tofu and vegetables 
Pad see iew with beef
Chicken noodles
Yellow curry chicken and potatoes

If you need a place to eat good food with great service, here ya go!!
author: Amie B.

description: I ordered Pad Kee Mao and Tod Man(fried fish cake) for dinner as take out. The Pad Kee Mao was bland. The pork was overcooked and chewy and no color. The noodles were soggy. It had onions and iceberg lettuce and tomatoes and serano chiles. This was NOT Pad Kee Mao. The Tod Man was meh. Again the seasoning was bland and not good.
author: Yoon P.

description:
We had a party of 3 and were seated right when we walked in. It took the server 15 mins to give us our menu, and ordering took another 15 mins. It wasn't busy but it took a long time to get our waiter to come by our table.
We ordered the shrimp fried rice, and pad thai. Probably the worst Thai food I ever had. It was mediocre didn't have much flavor to it. Kind of bland and dry. We never got our glass of water refilled not even at the end of our meal. Our waiter took so long to take our orders and was never attentive to our table. 

Wont be coming back again unless they fix their service. Only time they'd see me again is if i was drunk coming in here to eat, and  to wake up next day not remembering.
author: Cheryl Ann B.

description:
The pad thai was great! I really liked the pad thai woon sen also. 

My problem lies in the soups. They tasted really generic and in no way close to authentic. As I am from Thailand I really do like the strong flavors of Kha and ganglal in my soup but man the Tom Yum tasted like it came from a can. The soups were all terrible.

Soups are very important in a Thai restaurant so please fix this.
author: Nicolas S.

description:
Not guest friendly. My group of four went for dinner tonight as food is usually ok. Upon arrival at 7 pm. We were the only ones in he restaurant. We asked if we could have a four top table at the window so we could look out on he street below. Remember we were the ONLY ONES THERE.  I felt this was a simple request but they were not accommodating. It would have been a simple move to put two tables together. 
This happens to be the second bad experience here. The staff is not customer friendly or accommodating. Sad. This place used to be ok. As for  service, food is ok. Not the best but ok. Service is poor. It took a while to place or order but it came in a timely fashion. But no customer service as one would expect in a restaurant. Maybe leaving us alone was a good thing.
author: Chris W.

description: We site has a light dinner here, the food was bland and didn't feel nutritious . My gf and I got s headache 30 minutes after in the same spot of our head thinking maybe the put msg of something not good in the soup.
author: Aaron E.

description: I honestly love this place. The younger staff seems shy, but one of the ladies there is super sweet and talkative. It's always hard for me to find a place that makes Rad Nah, but this place makes it like my favorite Thai restaurant does when I growing up. Great view of the Castro and very quaint. If you're looking for good food and nice views, check them out!
author: Joey A.

description:
Coming back after a long hiatus, I was pleased with my visit this time around. Weekends around lunch time are usually crazy here but for some reason I was able to get a table by the window for my very green cousin to see all the Castro happenings.

The food was fresh, right temp and delicious. While my cousin, being the picky eater that she is wasn't as enamored she did find some pleasure in the chicken satay at least.

I need to come back more!
author: Steven G.

description:
Argh!  This used to be my go-to place for Thai food.  It's not wheelchair friendly as it's on the 2nd floor up a flight of stairs with no elevator, but it's delicious and conveniently close to home.  But I just came home with my pumpkin curry and found that they reduced their size to 30% less!  Here's a pic (drink is not included, I just put it there so you can see how SMALL the food size was for more than $14).
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yWja5zGBY3GSn_dtEXd7UA?select=UaY9Pwh34DT7NEW7BNg3Ig

Sure, maybe I need to excercise portion control but it's not the restaurant's place to force that on their customers.  PLUS, it was still $14+ dollars for this mini-curry size.  At least reduce your price to less than outrageous if you're going to reduce the food portion!  No utensils, no napkins, no rice, $14+!!!  No more TR!  No more... (I am angrily eating the curry while typing this :P ...or should I say hangrily eating...I just hate feeling ripped off)

p.s. they also scored a relatively low 85/100 on the Dec 2011 Health Inspection report.  Ick.
author: kiwi l.

description:
Rather entertaining to sit by the window. The chicken with baby corn vegetables is good.  My friend ordered curry salmon. Not sure why fish should drown in an otherwise good sweet sauce. Put it this way, I ended up sticking to my own dish. No family-style this time. Lol
By the way, it's so much better when the food server actually serves the Tom Yum soup. I had to volunteer to do the pouring and the soup was warm, not hot. 
Not throwing this place out the window. Will be back for another try.
author: David R.

description:
Met some friends here for dinner last night.  It was delicious and I'll definitely be back!

The restaurant is on the second level of a building on Castro St.  It's a smallish place, with the dining room overlooking the street and the big theatre across the way.  It's dimly lit with a neat red glow on white textured walls.  Pretty cool.

Service took a little while to get us started, but once the ball was rolling, they were very fast.  For a party of 5, we received our entrees promptly and all at the same time (I hate it when there's just one person still waiting to get their food and everyone else sits around awkwardly not eating theirs).  I had the spicy seafood in a clay pot and it was fricking awesome.  Tons of flavor and just enough spice to make my nose run but not burn my tastebuds off.  The only thing I didn't like about it was the taste of the mussels -- they are obviously frozen, not fresh.  Oh well.  My husband had the basil duck and inhaled it so I suppose it was edible at the very least.  O_o  My BFF had a crab pad Thai which looked awesome and is on my list to try next time.

Prices are actually very very reasonable, especially considering the location.  I'm always surprised when stuff in the heart of the City isn't set to break your bank account.  $12.95 for the clay pot entree.  Nice!  

The only bad thing is the parking in this neighborhood.  We were late for our reservation because it literally took us like 30 minutes to find a spot way out in the middle of fucking nowhere....we had to hire a midget Sherpa guide and a donkey named Bobo to guide us back.  So if you're driving in, plan ahead accordingly.
author: Heather K.

description: Delicious food. Pumpkin curry and green curry are favorites. The spicy fried fish looked amazing, but I didn't get to try it.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Sorry but this isn't good Thai food at all. The quality of the food is poor. Vegetables are not fresh and low quality. Few if any spices are used. I dont know if they use MSG but we both felt afterwards like they did use a lot of it. The service is very slow and not so friendly. 
I wouldn't recommend coming to this place.
author: Ddc C.

description:
I've eaten here before and I just recently came back for more. Located next to a bar (you can hear the thumping music from below), this place does not disappoint. Try the Thailand Ruam Mit (Appetizer Combo) for starters which include: Fried spring rolls, fish cakes, shrimp in a blanket, tofu and curry puffs served with several sauces, and tell me that's not good. For those that can't push through the sarcasm, it's delicious. 

Order yourself the Soft Shell Crab fried rice and Duck Curry, and you're good to go after your food coma nap. Order the spicy but lightly sauteed green beans too, it's a great combo of food.

The few drawbacks that I'd have to say was that they don't take American Express and the roar of music from below. Otherwise a pleasant meal is to be had, along with a usually attentive staff.
author: Johnas D.

description:
Great tasting Thai food  (very consistent) with much need of improvement with serving staff. 

I love coming to this place year after year. The food is top notch and very authentic. 

You can't go wrong with food. It really is a 5 start quality food but too bad the service is less than perfect by far.   The staffs are friendly but not very attentive at all. This has been the pattern since my first visit 10 some years but will not stop me from going there to eat. Food is that good!!
author: B K.

description: I was hesitant to come here because of the mixed reviews, but I was pleasantly surprised. The place itself is cold and not terribly inviting on a chilly day, but the food made up for it. We ordered the green curry and the sweet basil with chili (both with chicken). The green curry had a subtle but very nice flavor. The basil chicken was more flavorful and the portion size was much more generous. The food is mild here so if you want it spicy you have to ask for it. Most of the bad reviews are for service. The place was nearly empty today, so the service was fine, but when the food is this good, I'll take food over service anyway.
author: Jon G.

description:
I have been coming to this restaurant for years...and loving those veggie spring rolls for years.  And in fact, I wouldn't mind eating *nothing but* those veggie spring rolls for years...  :)

I have seen a couple of owners change over, but the place is always clean and the servers always friendly and helpful. 

Great for vegetarians and vegans.
author: Quality T.

description:
It was my second time eating here.  It's a hidden gem on Castro Street and if you are walking too fast, you might miss it!  I enjoyed the view - the Castro Theater and the bustle of Castro street with flashes of nude men.  Gotta love the Saturday lunches.  Because of the View, I was able to confirm Labor Day plans...watch Vertigo at the movies!  2 for 1.

What I did enjoy was the quick service.  There were a few customers, but they treated us quite attentively and even had two waiters approach us for drinks.  Appetizers came quickly as well as the food.

I've had better Thai food, but the food was good.  We had the red duck curry, it was delicious.  We also had the peanut prawns and the service size was good with surprise bed of steamed spinach underneath.  The appetizer combo dish with fried rolls, tofu, etc was also great.  When I stated mild, it really was mild (no spice actually), so I think it will be safe to say Medium spicy next.  I'll be back!
author: Neville B.

description:
Trust Yelp! We saw mixed reviews and hesitated, but let me be clear: Avoid this place if you can. 

Neither of our orders was what we expected, thanks partly to unclear menu writing and partly to a waiter accompanied by a "translator" who didn't seem to understand much English. 

The food itself was ok - Golden Calamari turns out to be deep-fried, which was not at all what the menu implied. The Calamari itself was good, but we didn't want big slabs of deep-fried breaded tourist food (?). 

We also tried the Pad Thai Woon Sen, which was not terrible, but not great. 

For most of the time we were there, the place was empty and the music sounded like bad karoake covers of songs I never liked in the first place. 

I am mystified as to why people would go here, when there are so many better options.
author: Sam Z.

description: The service was great. The restaurant was newly remodeled.  It was a little drafty. I had the cashew chicken, and my boyfriend had the duck. The food was great. If you are going there during the recommended a sweater.
author: Sarah B.

description:
This place used to be good.  Unfortunately, the restaurant is no longer delivering great food. 

Placed an order for take out tonight.  What we received was bland, unappetizing, and quite gross.  We asked for our dishes to come spicy, but I have to say I've made more authentic Thai food in my own kitchen for a whole lot less money.

My opinion:  If you're looking for decent Thai food, go anywhere but here.  If you're looking for great Thai food, you will definitely want to avoid eating here.
author: Brian F.

description:
Ok writing this review as I'm eating. Walked in for a quick lunch order to go. The gentleman was friendly. I ordered the Pad Ga Paw with beef.  Don't forget my Thai ice tea.

Got back to work with my food and realized it was mainly just onions & peppers. Once I pulled it all out there was pretty much nothing left. I dont like onions at all. I like the flavor it adds to food but dont want it in my mouth. Weird, right??

The flavor was quite tasty but you don't actually get a lot of meat. But if you like onions then go for it.
author: Ayana K.

description:
This is my favorite Thai place in San Francisco. Everything I've tried on the menu has been great, the staff is very nice and helpful, and the decor is fun (the walls looks like Legos). If you sit by the window you can people-watch on Castro St., which is always fun.

I took my brother who had never had Thai here a couple years ago and he still mentions it.
author: Bren C.

description:
Love everything here. 

Think the food, location, service, atmosphere is all wonderful.

Definitely recommend to anyone looking for Thai food in the City.
author: Niran L.

description: I remember coming here a long time ago. I'm glad this place is still here. I recently revisited this place with a friend and my partner. They had quite an extensive menu but not being adventurous we stuck with what we knew. Papaya salad, pad thai, red curry with pork, fried eggplant, baby corn with mushrooms and beef. Everything tasted yummy especially for me since that was my first meal of the day. All washed down with a cold Singha beer. Tummy happy!
author: Kenson K.

description:
Downgrading a star for delivery.

I ordered delivery from Thailand on Sunday night. They told me they were busy and it could be up to an hour. An hour went by, still no food. An hour an fifteen minutes, still no food. An hour and a half, still no food. So I called and the guy put me on hold. While I was on hold for 7 minutes, my food arrived. Which was hilarious, because when the guy got back on the line, he told me my food had just left and would arrive within the next 10 minutes, so clearly they have no idea what's going on with the delivery.

My green curry with chicken was extremely good (4 stars), but I thought both the string beans with tofu and the pad thai could use improvement.

Disappointed, as my experience with the food here before had been excellent.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Thailand Restaurant markets its vegetarian dishes on its outside sign, but it's no more vegetarian or vegan friendly than any other generic Thai restaurant.

I started off with the "gari paab" curry puff appetizer ($7). It was similar to mini samosas, basically. Not terribly interesting or flavorful.

For my main course I had the "gluten pad khing" ($8) which is the only dish on the menu using wheat gluten (tofu is an option for every other dish).

It was a basic soy sauce stir-fry. Nothing special and nothing I couldn't have made at home in 20 minutes or so. I asked them to make it spicy and all they did was dump some Sriracha sauce, which in the end just made it tongue-numbingly spicy. Not quite what I hoped for (I thought they would add some fresh green chilis to the dish).

Like many Bay Area Asian joints, they charged me $2 for rice, which is a horrible crime every time (in the Midwest where I'm from, or the East coast where I currently live, rice is always free). At least they had brown rice.

The service was mixed; one server was friendly while the other was curt, slow and inattentive.

I would not come back here.
author: Kedar D.

description:
29-November, Thursday 
Dining here oddly felt like I was embalmed in one particular episode of Seinfeld where there was the bright sleep-depriving neon sign from a Kenny Rogers' Rotisserie across that way that comically illuminated Kramer's apartment making him prone to insanity.  

Don't get me wrong, there was nothing wrong with my butterfly shrimp but the interior lights were so faintly dimmed (no bulbs in the place were above 15 watts), atmospheric lighting is one thing but dining in the dark is just uncomfortable. Especially with the aforementioned, it's a tad bit hysterical that the textured bulbous shapes lining one of the accent walls looks like enlarged Braille for a giant.
author: Ty T.

description: After our last order in September, we decided to give it a second chance.  To our surprise, we got the same delivery guy with the most unprofessional attitude.  After he gave us the food, we asked if we need to sign anything.  He said no, but he reminded us that we "didn't pay for tip online".  We were going to give him cash anyway, but were shocked that tip became a mandatory thing.  Then, he went on with how it was too far so we should not order for delivery again after he took the money.  We tried to call the restaurant and it went to their voicemail.  It is totally confirmed our decision not to ever order or eat at this restaurant again.
author: Casey N.

description: I have been eating here (well, most often take-out, so maybe "eating from here"?) since the 1980's. The food is reliably good, delivery usually quick, though they have sometimes gotten the order wrong in the past this (has not happened since online ordering became available.) They make a delicious "fresh spring roll" and also yummy papaya salad. Papaya salad can be very spicy at some places, sometimes too hot for me to enjoy, for me the  Thailand restaurant salad is just right.
author: Tom M.

description: Service took forever. Food was poor quality. What happened? Am I missing something or did this restaurant take a turn for the worst? Hoping this was a one off experience.
author: A. J. Dex C.

description: I have a good time when I eat here.  I tell them to make my dish(s) super spicy and they never do, so I end up emptying the assorted peppers/chili paste they bring out and I just pour those onto my plate.  I love sweating over spicy food!  hahaha!  The restaurant was remodeled a few years ago and for the better!  The place can get loud if it gets busy, so keep that in mind if you're seeking a place to chat or have a romantic dinner.  I think their prices are a smidgen high for the amount of food you receive and it's quality.
author: Shaun W.

description: Good food and nice view of the Castro theatre. The service was also good. The kitchen made me something that was not on the menu and the waiter checked on our party making sure everything was okay.
author: Joy H.

description:
Average

Order by the number, don't expect dishes to be ready at the same time, food is luke warm, as well.

Spicy sea fish curry, wasn't spicy at all, So nice place upstairs but not really worth going there again...
author: Ben B.

description: One piece of beef in the pad see ew one piece of chicken in the pad thai. Appetizers were soggy. Other than that every thing else wasnt that good.
author: Buck T.

description:
Was wondering, why they are not busy as before?! Now, I know, very poor customer service, oh my God to say very poor its big deal, they are way more down under poor service. Try to contact restaurant , and ask to speak with manager....he's not here, not coming in today , maybe hell be in next year, its ridiculous...Went over Sat night, stuff was busy watching TV, I guess was theirs favorite show on, not caring about guests, we couldn't get next round of drinks, every time different person will take an order.....etc


I WILL NEVER COME BACK, AND WILL ADVISE TO ALL MY FRIENDS TO PASS THIS RESTAURANT FROM NOW ON!!!!!!!
author: Emir L.

description: Good food, public $2 parking lot hidden across street. Food was all great Thai food, no complaints on serving size or quality.
author: Amanda P.

description: I ate here about 6 months ago. I had the pad see yew! It was good, portion size was big, and I loved the ambiance- nice decor and candle lit tables :) The location is really centralized in the neighborhood and very reasonably priced for the quality of the food and the restaurant's appearance. I will gladly come here again if I'm in the area and hungry!
author: Shav S.

description: Very tasty Tum Yum kai and the  Thai waitress girls were friendly! You should give it a try and see...
author: Seth U.

description: This place is so cute & the service is excellent. The food matches the service, it is fantastic. My favorites are the pineapple fried rice & the pad Thai. They even let me charge my phone.
author: Laura A.

description:
4 years since I first came to Thailand Restaurant and it is still the best Thai food I have had. The food is beyond amazing, I've tried so many different things and have never been disappointed! This place beats every Thai place in the City by far. 

The service is great, everyone is so nice and the food always gets out in a reasonable time. 

The ambiance and location of this restaurant (and it's sister restaurant) are perfect, it's in a fun part of the city with so much going on. 

I take all my friends and visiting family here and everyone always has the best time and loves the food. Seriously, you cannot go wrong here.
author: Cara S.

description:
I can't help but give this place five stars. 

Surprisingly good food? Check. 

Amazing window seat with a view of the Castro? Check

Attentive service? Check

Table of five hilarious bears comparing stories of sexual midadventures? Check. 

Fucking perfect.
author: Mel H.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant. I first came here because my friends recommended it and Thai food is our favorite girls night out meal. Thailand restaurant is a small restaurant with very friendly staff. 

My favorite dishes include pinapple fried rice (comes in a pineapple!) and pad Thai or pad see yew(both good) and of course the fried bananas. 

If I didn't live so far away I would eat here all the time. YUM!
author: Alyssa B.

description: I have had two varying experiences here.  One time I got a curry and pad thai and enjoyed it.  The other time I got a peanut sauce dish with chicken and spinach and was deeply underwhelmed by the runny quality of the sauce.  The prices are fine, but I don't know which direction my third direction will go - fine or mediocre.
author: Jeremy G.

description: Small & cute, pretty good menu , th bathroom is nice so is the staff and the interior design is lovely !
author: Ashana D.

description:
Oh ill make you feel REAL GOOD baby..... That's what the stripper said before taking your money. Then you go "that's it?"

I usually like this place for lunch, but what the heck happened today? I ordered the prik khing with pork and eggplant with chicken. I was imagining this would be so good, then when I opened the box, not bad. First bite. What is this? Cream of sum yung guy? It had enough oil and grease in both dishes to out do BP in the gulf. Thank god I have a box of cereal and milk in the fridge at work. Imma stick with my cornflakes like how I stick with my gfs. No more strip clubs for me I'm going to stay home from now on. Wait is this review for centerfolds?
author: Q L.

description: I ordered take-out from Thailand Restaurant via EAT 24. The food arrived and I gave the driver a cash tip. The next day, I was checking my bank account and discovered an additional $3 charge which I had not authorized. I called EAT 24 and they told me that the driver had called the restaurant and told them that "the customer said to add a $3 tip to the bill". Apparently, Thailand Restaurant uses a company called Sidecar to do its food deliveries. EAT 24 apologized and reimbursed me immediately. Thailand Restaurant has lost my business.
author: Cheryl L.

description: We went here for lunch... the food was cheap and was a good deal... but i felt like the dishes we ordered was kind of on the sweet side... not our taste... but i do like there pad thai tho!
author: Peter C.

description: As ambiguous as the name is, so is the food. I ordered the pad thai woon sen with chicken but about half of the protein was tofu. As a whole, I found the dish to flavorless and boring, very unlike other Thai I've experience. It also wasn't very filling, and I found myself hungry shortly after.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Still Faboo! Our elderly friend Inge wanted to return here for those lamb chops. It was a special before. No longer anywhere on the menu. They still fixed it for us. 

The neua yang came with a great dipping sauce. They actually had larb ped which was great and their pad kee mao which we got with chopped chicken tasted just right.

Service was great as always. Really great!
author: Nobbi L.

description:
Was it something I said Thailand Restaurant? I thought we were doing so well... like really clicking, I mean I was going to take you to meet my parents, I just bought you that bracelet you'd been eyeing up. That hot night in Vegas. Did you think I was looking at other Thai food? Because if that's it baby it's just not true. Or is this like that chick movie and you're just not that into me?

If you aren't breaking up with me then why the hell did your delivery guy just tell me I live "too far" away and he couldn't come anymore? You didn't have a problem delivering all those other times. No no, I get it, it's just "too hard" now that we're not at that new 'butterflies' stage in the relationship. Jesus TR, did you think relationships weren't going to be a little work? My god, the googles says I'm only 2 miles away! You didn't think that a little effort would be required to keep things so exciting?

So all those other times you delivered were just flings I suppose and now you're done with me. Fine. Yes I feel used, and don't look at me that way. Did you really have to make my mango sticky rice all hard and gross too? I can take a hint OK, you don't have to give me shittier quality food to scare me off.

I thought I loved you TR. I really did. But saying you won't come visit any more? How do you think that makes me feel? And giving me a crap dessert? I mean, can I even come visit you anymore? Or is that weird now?

How could you.. I still love you, but I think we should take some time apart.
author: Justin N.

description: The food is decent, but the service is terrible and in our case was embarrassing since we brought friends. Had to flag them down to order then half the food came out half an hour after the rest then had to flag again to get the check. (Seriously a half hour went by before we had to resort to waving them down...)
author: Heather R.

description: Ordered the pad Thai, one of the most basic dishes on any Thai restaurant's menu. They wouldn't add spice to it, and the flavour was lack luster at best. I won't be coming back here.
author: Chris S.

description: I read the reviews for this place and was extremely skeptical but I really wanted Thai food and the pricing seemed decent so we gave it a try. The decor of this place is really strange, its obviously converted from an old apartment, because it looks like they just knocked down the walls, put in a bunch of tables and made it a restaurant. I ordered the yellow curry with chicken and the flavor was pretty good. However, the curry was extremely watery (which i dislike) but the portions are really big. My friend ordered the duck fried rice which was extremely flavorful and tasty but really oily at the same time.
author: Isabella L.

description: After seeing Al Pacino's documentary "Wilde Salome" at the Castro Theater, we were hungry!  I spotted this Thai restaurant before the show, so we headed over after.  We ordered our standard pad see ew (yumm! great taste, mmm!) and egg rolls (cut into bite-sized pieces, piping hot and tasty), plus a healthy glass of red wine.  Perfect!  Great location right across the street from the Theater, near Castro Muni.  We'll be back when we're in the area, and especially when we're catching a show.
author: Maile N.

description: The worst Red curry I've ever had, very watery and without much taste, not spicy at all. Ordered red curry with duck and they were out of duck. Ordered some veggies with chicken and there was no chicken at all. Never will order from this place again!
author: Natalia M.

description:
Holy Shit !!! After a long day of lols hanging at the Wharf and watching all the tourists walk into each other or ride their bikes into each other, I decided to hit up the Castro district for some noms. I walked around for a while as I was a bit unsure of what I really wanted to eat. One of those days you just say...fuck it...whatever sounds good.
 I walked by this place and noticed it looked a little sketch, since you have to walk up stairs like going into a rub n tug massage parlor. Not that I would know ha. I get up there and it's a quaint little room with great natural light coming through the bay windows. I was seated right next to the window and got to people watch everyone enjoying this hella nice day. I ordered the bbq chicken lunch special with soup combo. HOLY effin donkey balls batman...the sweet and sour soup was soo on point. I'll probably go back tonight just for that. Then out came the bbq chicken. I scarffed that down in about 5 mins...would have been shorter but I was trying to write a yelp review from my phone while eating it. The service was great, the atmosphere a plus...and my neighbors at the other tables convos were hilarious. I tried not to eaves drop but when people are talking about sparkle ponies and what their gay uncle is doing with his mistress...how can you not?! I will be hitting this place up as my go to for Thai from now on. Whoever didn't give this place a good rating...you're just being a staunch kunt.
author: Mr. Potato G.

description:
Thai coconut Delicious 
Service sometimes are great and not. 
It's clean the bathroom and I like that , and fast service too. 
the sometimes pretending don't know English ....(don't get fooled by that)
author: B H.

description: Stumbled upon this little Thai restaurant yesterday with my boyfriend. We ordered from the lunch special, it was a little slow, lacked some ambiance, but our waitress was very nice. We are both vegan, which wasn't a problem at all, our waitress even had the kitchen whip up some vegetable soup the accompany our lunch. We had two of the curries, fried tofu, and a veggie version of the baby corn and mushrooms. Everything was very tasty! The tofu was fried to perfection. I will be hitting this place up again soon.
author: Sarah D.

description:
The food from here is generally good, no disappointments after 6 or so deliveries, and I'm a finicky vegan.  They have a good Pad Thai, a basic item that every Thai Restaurant needs to get off the ground.  Their fried spring rolls are also better than most; they give seven little ones rather than three medium, which ends up being a better value per inch of spring roll.  (But they could be a little less stingy with the sauce.)  Other favorites of mine are the Gluten Pad Khing (seitan to you and me), Pad Ma Keau (eggplant) and the vegetarian Tom Yum soup.  

I will be happy to give this place a better rating if they address certain menu deficiencies, to wit:  They have NO vegetarian yellow curry listed!  This is an outrage for a fan of Thai food.  They also have  pumpkin curry, recently added, but it does not provide a vegetarian option.  What are they thinking???  Part of the problem is that they have "vegetarian" sections to the menu, which is really unnecessary.  A vegetable entrees or ala carte  section sure, from which anyone can choose.  But vegetarian options ought to be offered on every appropriate item - where one also chooses beef or chicken, spicy or not, etc.  (And the vegetarian options should be "tofu" or "vegetables only", not just one or the other.)  

Yes, I could call and make the special request for these items - and forgo the convenience of the online ordering.  Or I could make the request in the notes section, but I've had less-than-stellar results with this restaurant and them not reading these notes.

Some attention to those details would go a long way.  They might even find those items in the menu with different names and the exact same description.  It's the attention to detail that matters.
author: Ken R.

description:
It was a really rainy day and my friends and I were really hungry and we happened to be in the area. My friend suggested this place so we went in.

The place has a very cozy feel to it, it looks like they converted a San Francisco skinny apartment into restaurant. They had music playing and a fish tank and all that jazz.

The food was once again, not so bad, and not so great, just kind of average. I ordered the pad-thai, which is what I ALWAYS end up getting because I usually don't order Thai food very often so don't know what else to get. and what's the most popular dish, pad-thai, so there you go, that's what I got.

The portions aren't so big for how much I paid. If anything, you're paying more for the atmosphere, which isn't so great either. There were a lot of people there for a weekday, which must mean something, but from what I tasted, I'm still searching for that "something."
author: Aurora P.

description:
I had the most awful lunch here. I had to go down the street and buy myself another lunch, it was that bad.

I ordered the Gai Ka Prow for lunch and it had the most funky ass smell. Not like the chicken had gone off - I wasn't worried about getting food poisoning but it was still nasty. I was like: what is that smell? Is it the fish sauce? Do they buy nasty fish sauce? Is it the bamboo shoot? They aren't supposed to be funky, are they? Etc. Finally after eating about a quarter of it, I left $10 on the table and ran out. 

I guess I could have sent it back, but really I just wanted to get out of there. There's something off about the whole room - parts of it are *beautiful* - there's all this gorgeous Victorian molding and a mantle, etc. But the walls are dark red with blue-white trim in a way that just doesn't go together. Likewise the modernist furniture clashes with the traditional setting. I don't know what's wrong here, but the energy is way off.

This restaurant has been around for a long time and I remember it being good but that was many years ago. It's all very sad.
author: Amy T.

description:
The food here at Thailand Restaurant was fairly typical Thai fare, though the staff and service wasn't the best. Great for a quick bite at lunch, but probably not for a nice dinner. The food was excellent tasting however, and I would definitely go back if I lived in the area.

Not the best Thai food I've had, but not the worst by far. Check it out if you're in the area for a quick lunch.
author: Ian M.

description:
this was my first meal at Thailand Restaurant, but it won't be the last.  i was in the castro and starved at lunch time and really craved thai food.  i went upstairs toward the restaurant not really knowing what to expect, but i was very pleasantly surprised.  the place itself seemed very clean and nice.  not upscale, just really nice.  

i had the 2 item lunch combo of green curry tofu and mixed veggies.  the presentation was unique and a bit fun.  the food was really delicious.  i should have specified that i wanted it really spicy because when it was served, it was only mildly spicy.  otherwise, it was just perfect.  

aside from the food, being able to look out the window beside my table and see the castro theatre and people bustling along castro street is something you really can't complain about :-)
author: Anjanette M.

description:
Let me start by saying there is a woman there (the owner perhaps) that is probably the most RUDEST person I have ever had to deal with at a restaurant. 

I was there with a group of about 16 friends and we gave them pretty good business, one of us asked her for utensils since there was not enough for everybody, she said "okay". We order and the food came out and still no utensils, when I brought it to her attention she raised her voice at me and said " You did not ask me for anything" as she rolled her eyes. I can understand if she was really busy, but our party was their only customers at the time.

The food was generic, their curry most likely comes from canned curry paste. 

THE BEST PART!

Towards the end of our dinner, the same rude woman walks up to our table of 16 and raised her voice saying " OKAY TIME TO COLLECT ALL THE MONEY". . . . Keep in mind some of us are still eating desert. Is she for real ? ! 

She waits for everybody to pay their share as she taps her feet and puts her hand out, I don't expect 5 star service, as long as there is some level of courtesy towards paying customers, this service is why none of us have any intentions on coming back.

In short, if you don't mind spending your money on horrible service and bad attitudes while you eat out then by all means, come here and get disrespected.
author: Hao N.

description: Spent the day yesterday attending the centennial celebration of Charlie Chaplin's character, The Little Tramp, at the Castro Theater, across the street from Thailand Restaurant. After the second of three sections of the film program, we were starving, and ran across the street to have some Thai food. We didn't have much time and when we let our server know that, she was very accommodating. I had the Pad Thai (online the menu description is rice noodles with egg, bean sprouts, onions and ground peanuts on the top) and I added chicken. There were also crisp shredded carrots in my dish; it was a good- sized portion and tasted very fresh.  My friend ordered the Pad See Ew -- pan fried flat noodles with broccoli and egg in light black soy sauce. I tried a bite of hers and it was delicious too. We both had the Thai iced tea to drink, and we were also given ice water without having to ask. Our food was brought out very promptly. Our table had a great view of the street below and the beautiful Castro Theater across the street. One can tell that the restaurant was converted from an apartment, but I don't see that as a negative at all! It's a great space that gives a warm feeling. The restaurant got very busy after we arrived but our service didn't suffer. I'd eat here again without a second thought. Yummy food, great location, wonderful atmosphere, good service. Hard to beat that.
author: Kimberly K.

description: Pad Thai, chicken yellow curry, eggplant... very decent. Fast service, good prices (especially the $5 cocktails). Almost walked into the bar below by mistake...
author: Maximillian M.

description: The food has been consistently fresh, flavorful and of the highest quality.  Having eaten at several Thai restaurants in SF, I can honestly say, that Thailand is my definite favorite.
author: DeeDee A.

description: This is only for the service. I hate giving 1 star but come on.... if i have to get up and my friends have to get up to get our own water...and spices and bill...and boxes...and entreee.....and coke... dang.... food was yum but service needs work. the layout of the place hinders the staffs view of their clientele.... they are literally hidden away blocked by pillars and shieet... pardon me language. christmas dinner fail! and please don't come up to us for a 15% tip during our appetizer.... that's automatic! i have many friends in the service industry and know how it works.
author: Shenni C.

description:
This Thai Restaurant is definitely great place to eat and catch up with friends.  I first went to this restaurant in the early 2000s and love it ever since.  The place is cozy and the waitresses are friendly. 
  
Eventhough it has changed ownership a couple years ago, I still love the place.  I come here whenver I can and I hope that you do too.

If you get the seatings next to the window on the left side, you can catch the historic Castro Theatre signage.  What more can one ask for on a cold foggy night in the Catro?  Great food and a glimpse history glowing across the street.

happy eating.
author: Truong P.

description:
Came here yesterday for some spring rolls and duck curry. Everything was just average fare, although it's nice to look out your window and see the bustling Castro street. Service was decent, but the portions were way too small: the curry came in this shallow little bowl. If they bumped up the portions, I may return.

If you're looking for thai, I prefer the one on Castro and 19th (fair warning, it can be really busy).
author: Sylvia L.

description:
This used to be my go-to place for thai food in the Castro but the quality has really gone down over the last 2 years.

The food used to be really good and the location can't be beat. Located right across from the Castro theater in surreal modern decorated former victorian flat it has a large menu with two pages of vegetarian options all at very reasonable prices. The most expensive dishes are around 12 dollars and most are under 10. 

The sad thing is that quality of the food has really gone downhill. The last two time we went the food was lukewarm and the seafood and the tofu was rubbery. Both the stuffed shrimp and the tofu for the tofu satay tasted like it has been cooked and frozen and then just heated up again. Dishes that used to be really good were just average and some were down right not tasty at all.

The service has also gone downhill. There doesn't seem to be a lot of communication between the staff about who has just arrived, who is waiting to order and if people are still waiting for dishes.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: Some of the best Thai food I have had, delivered to the table fast. Service was great, too.
author: Olga K.

description:
Food = great.  Good portions.  Great flavors.  Perfectly spicy.  The quality is very good on vegetables and seafood and meat.  The range of choices on the menu was great, for meat lovers, seafood lovers and vegetarians!  Yum.  

I had their spicy flat noodles with shrimps.  My friend had the chicken curry.  We also tried their curry puff, which was delightfully crispy on the outside, and perfectly soft and delicious on the inside with great peanut sauce.  I had a veggie soup, which was perfectly sour with lemongrass.  

Service = great.  Very attentive.  Friendly.  Efficient.  

Prices = very good for the great value of quality.  

Minus is that parking in the Castro is non-existent.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I am a big fan of Thai food and this place was pretty lame :-(

The wait staff was not very attentive. No one came to greet us or take a drink order until we had been sitting down browsing the menu for almost 10 minutes. Then at the end of the meal, we had to ask for the bill after our finished plates sat stacked on our table for a while. Maybe it was because they were close to closing, but I was a server for a long time, and managed to give my last tables at closing good service while completing my sidework. 

The decor and ambience was a bit strange as well. The lighting was turned down way too low...low enough that I was having trouble reading the menu and actually got up to turn the dimmer up myself. The walls are deep red and white and covered in over-sized dots, that looked like giant braille. It just seemed strange for a Thai restaurant. I could see how it would be a lot more appealing during the day.

We ordered the Tom Ka Goong (Shrimp Coconut Soup), Basil Shrimp, and Spicy Tofu Noodles. 

The soup tasted pretty watered down and there was no kaffir lime leaf, galangal, ginger, cilantro or lemongrass...all traditional thai spices one would expect to flavor any decent Tom Ka soup! The rest of the dishes also lacked the traditional palate of Thai spices, making them mediocre at best. 

The spicy dishes were only hot from the sliced raw jalapenos that were added. They did not even use Thai peppers/chilis. The shrimp tasted like pre-cooked frozen shrimp that had just been thawed and tossed into the wok last minute making them very bland. No searing of any kind could be seen on the shrimp or veggies. I have definitely made much more flavorful and authentic tasting Thai food at home just by using Thai curry paste and coconut milk!

Another disappointment was the lack of rice options.  Brown or Jasmine only, no sticky or coconut rice. 

If I were only reviewing the food I would give Thailand Restaurant 2 stars since the food didn't necessarily taste horrible, but it paled in comparison to other Thai food I have had. The dissapointing food combined with the off-putting ambience and inattentive wait staff brings my rating down to one star.
author: Shannon P.

description: Just OK.  Nothing extravagant or super fancy (although they do have burgundy cloth napkins!).  Food is decent.  I like the soju drinks, although I've had better.  A solid choice for consistently decent food, drinks, and satisfactory service.  My recommendation: The Pad Thai (although note that even if you up-order the chicken, it will still come with tofu (for all of you out there with soy allergies).  Felt a little "rushed" by the staff who never asked us if we wanted dessert and never came to check on us after the bill was delivered.
author: R. Karl H.

description:
Warning!!

This restaurant is DESPICABLE. I placed my order on their website at 8:15 and received a confirmation email.  After waiting an hour I called to check on the status of my order, however, the phone kept going to voice mail (which was full).  After calling over ten times (I wasn't sure at this point if I had been coned or what) I was fed up.  

After gathering more patience, I called once more at 10 (the time they supposedly close) to see if they would finally pick up their phone so I could at least get a refund (yes they charged my card).   They finally picked up.  I spoke to a man who said I never placed an order.  I told him the email confirmation number (I think he wanted me to let it drop).  I persisted until he finally said they did get the order but not until just now (almost 2 hours later, I don't think so).  He said he would try to figure out how to refund my card and would call me back when he did.  I did not receive any call.  In fact, after finally getting a hold of the manger several days and calls later I was reassured by card would be credited (but it would take one week).  After several weeks of this game, seriously, I walked into the restaurant and demanded my money back.  They tried to insist that I wait one more week for the transaction to go through; I told them no.  I had waited weeks (5) at this point.  I told them I would be standing there until I got my money back for the food I never received! I walked out with my money and will never, ever be ordering from this place again.  

Bonus bad points for calling me a liar after not delivering my food.  I always enjoy being yelled at on an empty stomach.
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
I haven't been to this restaurant since the 80's and it was fantastic back then.  Well, I'm happy to report that it's still fantastic!

The Chicken Satay was incredible!  It was perfectly bbq'd and had a fantastic peanut sauce.  However, I've always loved their cucumber side.   I only wish that it was a bigger portion because it's that good!

The Penang Curry with shrimp was incredible.  The sauce included peas, carrots and was perfect.  Not spicy and definitely not bland.  A necessary dish for any Thai food excursion.

The most surprising dish was the Spinach and Tofu in Peanut Sauce and it was the bomb!   The spinach was cooked to green perfection and is the perfect compliment to the peanut sauce.  However, the tofu takes the cake here.  In virtually every other Thai restaurant, they use smooth tofu.  However, here, they use a very thin deep friend tofu and is coated with peanuts.  Wow!  The tofu was not greasy at all and provided that contrasting texture to the peanut sauce and spinach that makes this a signature dish for the Thailand Restaurant.

Lastly, who can resist a fine glass of Thai Iced Tea!  

The ambiance is excellent.  It looks like they added an interesting brail wall paper that gives the restaurant a very modern feeling.  The modern furniture and lighting are a nice contrast to the formality of the Victorian wood work.  Anways, it's very romantic and you can see the Castro Theater just outside the window.  

I have to say that I find this to be the best Thai restaurant in the Castro after all.  Like most Thai restaurants, it's not the cheapest food option, but it's completely worth the price.  The service was fast, friendly and excellent too.
author: Dougg K.

description: The food was alright, but nothing notable.  The service was pretty bad though.  The waiter had no personality, and he never came by to fill our water glasses or to ask how the food was.  A side of peanut sauce cost $3 and it was only enough to dip 2-3 pieces of tofu in.  If you're going to give so little of something that costs you nothing, then at least charge $1-1.50, not $3.  Rip-off.  Oh, and the music was terrible.  They literally played music you'd find on a Disney soundtrack...
author: Jacob A.

description:
3.5 stars since the dinner was... 
1. Fast
2. well portioned 
3. reasonably priced

The restaurant is clean ane the service is ok. It is a very tiny former apartment turned into a restaurant type of setting!  The window seats are good for looking at the Castro's traffic and activity and the goldfish aquarium and the waterfall are also eye pleasing. The water just keeps on coming with ice cubes with lemon slices and this place has much more ambiance than other places! The interior decoration and setting are wonderful like the square places, drinking glasses, burgundy cloth napkins and even the silverware.
author: R C.

description: BEWARE!!! This place will seriously rip you off!! They are clearly DESPERATE in an attempt to salvage a failing business. Seven friends and I went for dinner..:the check arrived and the total was $366.00. Upon further review and analysis we realized that they attempted to scam us; for in actuality the bill should have only been $210.00. All the staff could do was say sorry. Clearly they were trying to pull a fast one! Very sad for the food is good BUT we will not return!!! This WAS NOT an honest mistake!!
author: Todd J.

description:
This review is only for delivery, so for the food itself and the delivery.  I'd put this at 3.5 stars, but the delivery was extremely fast (about 20 min even though website said 45-60) so thanks for that.

Tom Yum Goong - different than most I've had in the states, but one of the best ones I'd say.  It's extremely rich/deep for a tom yum, so maybe they'd been steeping this batch of broth longer or with more shrimp heads/shells in it.  Could have used a few more shrimp in the actual dish, but there were tons of mushrooms.  We ordered it "Spicy" and it was extremely spicy - of which we are huge fans.  From the other yelp reviews (and perhaps obviously) it would seem that the level of spice you get is based on who's cooking that dish, so I guess we lucked out.  Will definitely be getting this again.

Papaya salad - also spicy, but not very memorable on the whole.  There was nothing particularly wrong with it, I suppose the papaya was a little flavorless, but all in all nothing great.
