I'd probably get it again to give it another try (or to fill out the minimum order if we get delivery) but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.

Beef salad - unfortunately a big strike on the evening.  The meat tasted a bit... leathery, so perhaps it was just on the older side.  Which is not how I prefer my perishables.  Very gritty, and not flavorful (other than the leather, as above).  Also, while normally I'd be thrilled to get such a high meat-to-greenery ratio, with this meat I kinda wanted some more vegetables in the dish just to have something else.

So again, 3.5 for the food, + 0.5 for prompt delivery - get the soup, avoid the beef salad.
author: Jake D.

description: An hour and 50 minutes for delivery? You have to be kidding me? When I called they didn't even care.
author: Brad W.

description: I think this is one of the best Thai restaurants in SF. The food is consistently well prepared, tasty, and attractive. The staff is sincere and friendly.
author: Daniel K.

description:
After spending time shopping with girls gang today, we decided to go to this restaurant  to get some appetizers. First, I would say I normally don't go out for Thai food, cuz I am Thai and I love to cook my own Thai food at home when i have time. However, i was glad that i went to this one.

We ordered such as
Tod Mun : fish cakes, were really good.
Som Tum: Papaya salad: hell yeahhh I totally would come back for this dish! 
Sea food salad: as good as it get! 
and Thai iced tea with boba( tapioca balls) Yum!

The service was great too.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Came here prior to catching a flick at the Castro Theater for the SFIAAFF, which is right across the street.

This place is pretty yum and is a prime spot for a date if you are going to watch a movie across the street at the Castro theater.  How do I know this?...because I went on a bromance date with one of my cohortian colleagues from school to watch a movie during the Asian American film fest.

We caught a 4pm show of the movie The Message, which was a very dope mystery movie that we caught at the Castro Theater.  Before that we grabbed lunch at this spot and ordered some tasty tom yum soup.  We sat next to the window, which had a dope view of the street.  The interior decor is pretty cool too.  So if you wanna kill two birds with one stone do the thai restaurant and movie at the castro combo and you can't go wrong.
author: Mark L.

description: My favorite everyday style restaurant in SF. Really delicious, flavory, big portions and good prices (for SF). Service is also good what is unbelievable for SF middle rated eatery, all other restaurants around are really rude here
author: Iv S.

description: $10 will get you a good amount of food for lunch.  They have special lunch deals.  I believe for under $9 you can get 2 items with rice and tom yum soup.  How cheap can this place be?  The service is great, the food is good.  What more do you want?  I came here a few times for lunch.  The place is quite small, atmosphere is nice and bright.  They also serve tapioca if you are interested.  Make sure you request for tapioca in your thai ice tea if you prefer to chew and drink at the same time :)
author: Mimi S.

description:
There is an abundance of Thai restaurants around the Bay Area , same goes for San Francisco. In the Castro alone i believe there are three. But i found this quaint little restaurant very inviting because of its location just across from the historic Castro Theater. The place has been remodelled about 3 times since i first dined here. The place is very clean and casual ( i always get a window seat whenever i come here for lunch so i get a view of the bustling castro crowd. A very wide selection of familiar Thai cuisine served in generous portions. Very presentable plating presentations, the staff are very friendly and attentive. One of my favorites is the crispy shrimp roll with a sweet and sour dipping sauce( you can choose a different type of sauce if you so wish). Curry for which thailand is famous for are scrumptious and creamy, available in white, red or green curry sauce. Reminded me of the time i went to Phuket Thailand to receive my award as a presidents club awardee for Fuji Xerox. The taste is very authentically Thai!

Street parking, the place was never crowded everytime i come here(but will probably depend if there is an event close  by).
author: lenra a.

description:
There's not that many Thai restaurants in the area (or in the Mission district) so I decided to try this spot.  Parking could be tough but I know public transportation is just a hop, skip, and jump away.
Anyhow, the food wan't anything to brag about.  It's decent and priced okay.
author: Ricky M.

description:
Ok, so this review is more about nostalgia than about anything current: food, atmosphere, service.

I am giving Thailand Restaurant 5 stars solely because it was the restaurant my husband took me to on our first date. He'd never had Thai food before but on the recommendation of a sibling and from seeing it while sightseeing in SF he decided to bring me here. 

He now loves Thai food, and well, me!

I can't remember what we ate or how the service was, but I do remember falling in love.

Thanks, Thailand Restaurant!
author: Mary P.

description: One of my favorite Thai places in SF! There are a couple of things that I love about this place. For instance, the decor is a fusion of art deco with a Thai twist to it. Also, it's right on Castro street and has a great view of the district. Their lunch special is reasonable for San Francisco prices. This is a place where the locals go and grab a quick bite and unwind. I recommend going for their lunch-combo special, you can't beat all that food for ten bucks.
author: Joseph P.

description:
Delicious. Convenient location. The decor is very clean and modern. My only gripe is that I wished they were more generous with the ingredients. The chicken in the yellow curry was a bit skimpy. Overall it was good and I'd go back. 

Shot out to Justin N. Your review is probably one of my favorite reviews on yelp.
author: Kelly M.

description: First place we ate at as we settled into San Fran.  Delicious basil fried rice and the pumpkin chicken curry was beyond delicious!  The spicy green beans with tofu was also very flavorful.  Would definitely eat there again.
author: Kameron H.

description:
I'm reviewing the delivery here...which may be different from the restaurant menu.  Good standby delivery place - they're usually quick. 

The food is ok. It's nothing spectacular, but it does the trick for thai delivery. My main complaint about the food is that it's usually soooooooo salty, like make sure you have lots of water salty...or feel dehydrated after you eat it salty.  

My fav dish is the pineapple fried rice - it has chicken and shrimp, and a great flavor. It's goes really well with curry too. 

If you live in the Castro/Twin Peaks area- this place is pretty solid delivery.
author: Lauren F.

description:
I know I give a lot of good ratings, but I think I have been lucky with the establishments I have visited.

I came here with a friend on a whim, and I'll be honest, pleasantly shocked. At first, we didn't know what we were getting ourselves into, but once we got upstairs and got a table at the window (looking down on Castro) and got to eat some tasty food. They have a vegetarian section too (great for me!). My friend got the pumpkin curry and it looked and smelled delicious. I got this soup, it was good, but I think I tasted soap on the spoon - which kind of bothered me, but not a showstopper.

Either way, have plans on going back
author: Leslie T.

description:
This place is pretty good. I ordered the Panang Curry lunch special. It came with rice and salad....only 7 bucks! 

I will be coming here more often :)
author: Nene D.

description:
I have always loved this place since the first time that I went like I think almost ten years ago !   My last bf and I use to come to SF from OC since 1998 until 2007 when he moved to England, and I remember coming here at least once every visit. 
Then I moved here in 2007 and have been going religiously !   
I did love it more when it was all comfy and homelike until 2009 when they changed it to modern whatev with bumpy walls...  but oh well - the Staff has always been super nice to me and always remembers me ! and tries to give me the best spot =   which of course is by the window. But the main things are that the food is good and the prices are reasonable !!!

And you can't forget that the bars are just below you cause it's on the second floor !
author: Robert F.

description: Very tasty pumpkin curry with duck, the BBQ pork was also delicious, combined with a side order of excellent brown rice. The service was attentive and everyone was welcoming. If you are looking for Thai food in the Castro you will definitely want to come here.
author: Bill B.

description: I've been eating here, in house and delivery for years. The food is very good, but from now on I'll seek my Thai food elsewhere. I ordered food at 7:30pm, and live four blocks from the restaurant. After an hour, I called and was told my food was on the way. Half an hour later, I called to cancel the order and was told that they refused to do it because the food (which I am sure is cold) had already left. It's now been over an hour and a half and there is no sign of thus food.
author: Trixie R.

description:
I would not have known that this place with upstairs, if I had not be really hyper vigilante as I looked for a restaurant to eat at.

The only thing that I did not like when I went was they waitstaff did not tell that loud women to get off her cell phone.  It was disturbing to try to eat a nice meal that was so delicious w/o someone yelling into their cell phone.

In any case, I love this place.   For an appetizer I had  the delicious and crunchy  Thailand Rolls (Spring Rolls).  Most are to greasy, but these were just right.  For a main dish I had the  Pad Thai.  I know it is a basic and standard dish, but I love Pad Thai.  For desert I had the 
Fried Banana with Honey.  Yummy and I was in heaven.

I love this place and they have take out as well.
author: Vanilla C.

description: I've been here many times over the years and the food has been consistently pretty good.  It's a nice place for a casual Thai dinner and reasonable prices. The portions are not huge but neither are the prices. The staff are quite friendly and attentive and keep the restaurant pretty clean. They also offer take out food that is prepared quickly after phoning in your order and ready for pick up (believe they offer delivery but it's quicker for me to walk over and get it myself).
author: Kent W.

description:
Decent food with a great view at fair prices...

The service can be a little lackluster...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Normally the food is pretty good and of consistent quality, which is why we decided to have dinner here after catching "Nine" at the Castro Theatre on Christmas Day. But unfortunately the food was even more mediocre than the film. Half way through the meal I asked my husband if he thought the food was as bad as I thought it was and he nodded his head.

The Pla Saam Ros (Three Taste Fish), was more like One Taste Fish, so downed in sweet sauce as to hide the fact it was way overcooked and  rubbery. The Pad Ga Praw (Spicy Basil) with pork instead of chicken seemed stale to the taste, reminding me of week-old left overs. The disappointing meal was made complete with dried out brown rice and watered down Thai Ice Teas. 

We frequent many Thai restaurants here and on the peninsula and this is the worst we've had in some time. Perhaps they had a substitute chef that night... or they served us microwaved leftovers from the previous night. Whatever the case we won't be back at least for a while.
author: Elvis M.

description: I recently discovered this place a few months ago and have been here several times since then. It has good food, it is reasonably priced, and not usually crowded. You might miss it if you are walking along Castro as it is above a bar or a store or something. It is definitely worth a try. The only reason it did not get a better mark from me is that the service is sometimes spotty.
author: Chris D.

description:
What? No Sticky Rice? Any Thai restaurant that doesn't serve sticky rice will automatically get 3 stars from me. 

Other than that, the food was fine. The red curry was good (served tongue scoldingly hot) and only $6.95 with jasmine rice and a very non-Thai iceberg salad. It was a decent cheap lunch and I'd be willing to go back to try some other entrees. 

The upstairs location is cute and it's cool if you can get one of the two tables with a view over Castro St. The server was very nice with a flirtatious smile.
author: Rex D.

description:
I like the food but this restaurant had two problems that will keep me from coming back again.  1st problem, the wait staff barely understands English and trying to order can be difficult.  Plus, for the second time eating there, we were brought food we did not order.  The first time, I asked for a cup of soup, the waitress kept saying bowl, I kept saying "CUP" (no I didn't yell but wanted to).  Anyway, they brought me a cup but later in the meal they brought a bowl.  I explained to the person bringing the bowl that I ordered a cup and had already ate it but (as I said earlier) he didn't understand my English and looked confused.  He did take away the bowl.  Then the bill came (PROBLEM NUMBER 2) which is written in Thai (I'm guessing it was Thai since I don't speak or read Thai) and they charged me for a bowl (I only knew this when I asked them to interpret the bill for me).
So to make this short, same thing happened yesterday only this time my partner ordered a salmon item but then the server explained the "specials" and my partner changed his order, and made sure the waiter understood (at least we thought he did).  Guess what?  Both the special and the salmon dish was ordered and when we asked why the waiter pointed at me and said I wanted it!!!! I ordered a soft shell crab dish and pointed out what I wanted to him on the menu so I have NO idea how I became the guilty party. 
Any way even though I like the food, NEVER AGAIN.  They need to give me a bill in English so I know I am paying for what I ordered and they need to get the waiters into ESL so that they can take orders in English and understand what the customers are saying.  Too bad, as I said I like the food.  The soft shell crab was delicious!
author: Gary C.

description: Great Tom Kah soup! LOVE their brown rice...I mean LOVE! I had the cashew nut chicken and my friend had the beef. They were both good...I think I prefer the beef. The hot tea was so good and the people are nice.
author: Kellie N.

description:
OK,
So, I had to get a quick bite with my daughter before a school assembly-no time to go home. The food was light and delicious! I am a huge fan of cold rolls and these were quite unique-stuffed with shrimp, Chinese sausage,bean sprouts,bits of fried tofu all wrapped in wide rice noodles. We shared a plate of pad Thai that was killer-extremely intense flavor, yet not overloaded.
I ordered the sirloin BBQ beef with a spicy lime sauce for my famished husband to quaff before the assembly-which exuded a smoky, grilled flavor and jived very well with the piquant dip.
Great service, yet not hovering. This would make a great date restaurant-especially if one stops here before a movie across the street...
All in all, an elegant respite (crimson walls ,serene decor) with great views of the grand Castro Theater and the throng of passersby.
author: Antoinette S.

description:
Really yummy and consistently good food! Got the fried tofu and fresh spring rolls appetizers...SO good! The tamarind and sweet & sour sauces are to die for.

I've had the Pad See Ew and pineapple fried rice...both super delicious and fresh. Not oily, greasy, or too salty like other places.

An awesome spot to go before hitting the bar!
author: Alan H.

description:
They get points for not screwing around with the name, calling it like it is. Why call a restaurant by anything other than what it really is?  Plus, they have a cool neon sign, of which we need to see more use of outside the Castro because neon anything rocks. Though the awesome sign is what attracted me to it, you can't judge a book by it's cover, so we strolled through the door, up the stairs, and into what looked like someone's livingroom.

The Pad Thai was pretty flavorful and sweet, not dry at all, served with prawns and tofu. I really like my Pad Thai wet, versus the dry-style you sometimes get, and they served it right in between. The chicken was served in three thin cutlets, cooked well with the oh-so-crucial grill marks and served with a sweet & spicy sauce that was very good. The chicken itself was okay, but the accompanying sauce made it better. So much so, that we asked for an extra side of the sauce and really laid it on thick.

Check out my in-depth feature with photos on my blog, link on profile.
author: Gene M.

description:
Thailand Restaurant foregoes a clever moniker to deliver delicious versions of your favorite Thai dishes, inexpensively. Literally, they deliver the goods to our door, faster than I can pronounce the exotic / geographic names of other places.

My first visit here was quite by accident. Due to my logistical errors, a number of Zukos and Pink Ladies were no-show for Sing-A-Long Grease at the Castro. The one Pink Lady who did make it walked all the way from his home. Lacking our chorus, we aborted the mission (Rizzo!) and headed across the street for Thai.

We had a delightful dinner upstairs in the cozy, verdant dining room. This meatatarian (tm Kevin S.) opted for some vegan tofu dishes on recommendation from my dining companion. Both were fantastic, with the tofu cooked perfectly - slightly crispy on the outside, soft and melty on the inside. Delicious with the brown rice they offer. We dined and gossiped about fashion, relationships, Yelp drama and Bravo TV.

So I had a first date with a man...and it was way less gay than my initial plans.
author: Andy R.

description: I've been to many Thai restaurants, and this one has a great clean place. I had high expectations since the ambiance of the place is nice and quaint. The dishes and glasses are very Crate and Barrel. There's candles and low light lamps. Pretty romantic. The food has great presentation, however there was two of us-the portions are like maybe a small child. I'm telling you the portions are SMALL! I felt like the meal we ordered was a appetizer! The bill was high, and 2 cokes was $6.00! I'd advise you to only come here if you have a meeting and need light snacks. T
author: Marie P.

description: Had a very pleasant meal here. Crisp tasty angel wings. Papaya salad for my wife which she ordered not spicy and it was still really full of flavor. I had the tom ka gai and it was just what my upset stomach craved. Then back across to the Castro for more of the Jewish Film Festival.
author: Marco M.

description:
I reviewed this restaurant under a duplicate entry with only two reviews. Oops, but there's no real way to alert Yelp to get the duplicate out of here. I was just about to say... everyone and their mother seems to have eaten here, but... only one review?

It's Thai food, typical yet iconic. The basil-infused dishes just keep making me return for more, and the clay pot specials are great comfort food any month of the year. Of the Castro Thai restaurants, this is the one I have frequented the most.

This restaurant certainly is not handicap accessible, occupying the second floor of the building, so just keep that in mind in the uncommon case that your dinner mates cannot climb stairs (which included me for a few months in 2004!). The restaurant is NOT good for kids, unless your kids are ok with gay guys talking about how big their dicks are while your family munches on satay.
author: Daniel C.

description: An upstairs spot with a view of the Castro theater and a lovely thumping feeling that is the bar on the ground floor. Food was good, not great. Service was acceptable, not exceptional. Vibe was right.
author: Will R.

description:
This is my favorite Thai restaurant.  I first discovered this gem while visiting sf for a friend art showing in the neighborhood winter '08.  It was love at first bite.  I've yet to find a better Pad See Eiw. 

Just about every visit to the city since then has included a stop at Thailand Restaurant.

I moved to bay area this summer and have shared my love for this place with all of my friends.  

Great food.  Warm atmosphere.  Good prices.
author: Nicole T.

description: My favorite Thai restaurant in San Francisco, which was a surprise given the unoriginal name.  For whatever it's worth, I've traveled extensively throughout Thailand, and I feel I have a good understanding of what makes a good Thai dish.  Luckily, so do they.
author: Ryan S.

description:
This is the only Thai restaurant in the US I can go to right after coming home from Thailand with no complaints!  The food is great, authentic and fresh.  If you want Thai-hot, you can get it here.

People watching on Castro is a bonus.  Get a window seat if you can.
author: Nadine J.

description:
Walked in looking for fast take out.  Didn't have very high expectations, but was pleasantly surprised.   It's basically your average hole in the wall (it's in the Castro, but that's not literal) Thai restaurant.  Worn out, but kind of cozy.  I can't comment on the dining room service, but whenever we go in to order take out everyone is extremely friendly and they always bring us hot tea or glasses or iced lemon water while we look at the menu.  How nice is that??  

The Gai Him Ma Pan (cashew chicken) was our "safe" order and was really good.  The captain says that the Pad Talay (spicy seafood) is possibly better than what he gets at Pad Thai in the mission.   The Pa Nang curry is also great.
author: P J.

description:
Awful. Ruined my romantic date. So you advertise as vegetarian on your sign, and you have a large vegetarian section in your menu; why the hell do you put fish sauce in my god damn vegetarian soup. 
I will never ever go back to this place. Nor should you.
Awful.

P.S. The rest of the food sucked too. Barf.
author: Rory V.

description:
This place is totally solid.
The decor is nicely modern, with braille-inspired wall treatment (nipples with your food, anyone?) and water features near the restrooms (mmm who doesn't love water sports over rice?).
The food is fantastic, perhaps the best Thai in the Central flatlands. I haven't had one of the appetizers that is anything but fried perfection; as usual, they are not the healthiest part of the meal but are worth the calories every now and then (try the curry puffs, they are delectable). Curries are medium-spicy and rich, but strongly curried and bound to impress. Noodles a little greasy but bursting with flavor --- their Pad See Eew is fabulous as a main dish. The pineapple fried rice is served in a hollowed out pineapple half, great if you want the coolest dish at the table. Two thumbs up!
author: Jay A.

description:
I'm behind on my reviews.  

I've been bookmarking and then forgetting about them.

The dr. and I found ourselves on his couch one Sunday evening lamenting our angry empty bellies.

"We haven't eaten since 10:30AM!!"

"I know!  Wtf?!"

"So hungry."

"Totally."

"Totally."

I think we talked about how hungry we were for an hour before it dawned on us that food was not going to magically appear so we put on shoes and made our way to Thailand Restaurant, mainly because it was across the street from  naia and we both anticipated gelato in our future.

But the minute we sat down and the ordering began, it didn't stop.  Thai Veggie Samosas.  Veggie Thom Kha soup.  Tofu Praram. Pad Kee Mao.

And tea.  For me.  (it was cold)

We sat as our blood sugar dropped well below normal.  I stuffed a samosa into my mouth the moment they landed on the table.

Mmmmmmmm.

The soup was excellent (again, i was cold) and I've always had a special place in my heart for thom kha in all its coconutty glory.

The tofu praram was good, but the peanut sauce seemed a bit sweet and  could be overwhleming if not combated with a gigantic forkful of rice.  The pad kee mao was a reliable standby.  Give me a plate of fat noodles anyday and I will lick it clean.

Except after a day of shrunken stomaches and a 3 course meal, there was no way I could lick anything clean after dinner.

So we left the Castro sans naia gelato.

So Thailand Restaurant?  I'd hit it.  Again.
author: Jen I.

description:
Upstairs Thai.  For the longest time that is what I thought the name of the restaurant was.  Ooops.  Oh well.  I still refer it as such, and probably will continue to do so forever.  

We had dinner here last night, and I have to say the food was great.  Three of us were meat eaters, and one vegetarian.  I've been here for both lunch and dinner, and this last visit has by far been the best.  Before last night, I would have considered "Upstairs Thai" average at best.  Perhaps they've changed cooks?  

Last night we had the Beef Salad, Tofu Satay, Vegetarian Green Curry, Red Curry Chicken, Spicy Eggplant, and Pad See You with Beef.  All very delicious.  Pad See You with Beef has to be one of my favorite Thai dishes anywhere, this one did not fail in comparison.  It was surprisingly good.  With the addition of some crushed peanuts and dried chili flakes it was ON HIT!  

For right now, "Upstairs Thai" gets three stars, per my previous experiences here.  However, we will return, and hopefully the improvement stays consistent, therefore deserving of four.  MMMmmm, Pad See You, I'm coming for YOU!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Here I am, stuck at a crossroads. I've only been to this restaurant twice. The first time was a great experience, a small,  upstairs Thai restaurant with a decent look-down view on Castro, with the theatre's red neon glowing in your face if you're lucky enough to be seated at the window. (But only if you're in a party of two, it's all that fits in the window nook) The food was great.

Fast-forward to visit number 2. Same nook. Same table. Same neon. Same service. Different results. I had a stomach-ache that caused me to pray to the porcelain toilet god, ass-down. 

So, what is one to do? Can I blame the restaurant for my body malfunction? Was my sickness a fluke? Or, perhaps, my body's positive reaction on visit #1 was just a fluke? 

Either way, with an over-abundance of Thai places in the city, I don't think I'll be going back to see which one was a fluke. But I'll give the place credit for its view, service and visit #1.
author: Bryan B.

description: Curry puffs were fun and flavorful. Shrimp wantons were uninspiring but fine. Chix Praw was also good enough...I enjoyed it, but it didn't elicit any exclamations. Not speedy delivery. Full restaurant size servings. I'd eat/ order from here again.
author: Mathew S.

description:
Blecko.

Monday lunch, red curry.

I knew I was in trouble when the server said, "Jose, I need a #3..."
author: Peter A.

description:
This is probably my favorite Thai restaurant in the Bay Area.

In fact, yesterday I went there for lunch (their lunch specials, $6-8, are a good deal and it's not crowded during the weekdays) and got red curry tofu and Thai coffee, which was good. But today for dinner, I was with a friend and somehow I found myself saying "I ate at Thailand Restaurant yesterday, _but I'll go there again_" (see what I mean?), to which he said something to the effect of "Yeah, that place is really good." So I found myself eating there for the second day in a row. We both got pad see ew. I got the vegetarian version, and the tofu was perfectly pan-fried: crispy yet soft on the inside. Amazing. (I just bumped up my rating to a full 5-stars, which I don't do often.)

I remember that their pineapple fried rice is great, too. I'm looking forward to getting that next time. Perhaps it'll be tomorrow.
author: John C.

description:
great hours.  good food.  good service.  good prices.

the seasoning here is subtle and complete.  

strange thing to say, but too many thai places beat you over the head with some sweat curry flavor and you miss out on the complex and rich tones of the fish, the duck, or basil, or sprouts, or onion, or cucumber.  these things have their own flavors.  it's not all about the sauce.

the view from the window is really enjoyable, too.  :)
author: Peter K.

description: Tasty, affordable and friendly Thai service. I like coming here, especially if I've been drinking all day, and need something to suck up all the liquor in me. The other night our group of 6 stumbled in, and got a table in 3 minutes. I love how they are specific on the wait time. We ordered family style, and shared green/yellow curry, pork/broccoli, pad see eww, and a seafood/rice noodle dish. Everything was tasty. The service they give is also top notch, they are attentive, friendly, and apologetic, even for a slight delay in dishes coming out. Prices are VERY affordable, so you can give them extra tip for giving you great service. Keep it up..
author: Thomas L.

description: The sloooooooooowest service with mediocre food.  So mediocre I don't even remember what I ordered.
author: Michelle C.

description:
Yet another purple walled Thai restaurant, it's located up a flight of stairs with the dining area above Castro Street.  The food is very good.  (Try the curry puffs as an appetizer.)  The dishes are well-presented, yet the food manages to fill the plate.  Service was delightful and attentive.  They offer free delivery with a $16 minimum (such an odd number for delivery).  

If you're looking for Thai food in the Castro with less of a fast-food atmosphere, skip Thai House Express down the street and come here.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Service is fast and friendly, green papaya salad and soups are good, but don't get the crab-stuffed butterfly shrimp.  Tasteless.

Not the best Thai restaurant in the city but it'll do when you're in the Castro and need food fast.
author: Asteridae A.

description: I love the coconut chicken soup.. and pretty much everything else I've ever had. Service is great and I love the atmosphere
author: Ryan G.

description: I love this place. The owner is super nice and have been good friends of a couple of my friends and we're always treated with such great service, respect, and warmth. I love the decor, the location, and the food. It's a great place to eat before a night on the town. Just be wary of your surroundings of the Castro isn't your scene.
author: Rosavida C.

description: yuck!  The tofu satay was so weird, the texture of the tofu was doughy, chewy and marshmellow like. It was a texture I never knew possible.  I also had the fresh spring rolls which had a fake meat that had a flavor unlike anything I've ever had before and would like never to have again.  And lastly the pad thai was all stuck together, also strangely flavored and all in all, one of the worst pad thai's i've ever had.  SO sad to have been so grossed out by my meal.  Just wanted to write this as a heads up for the vegetarians out there, if you eat here, steer clear of these items.  Yuck!
author: Priscilla L.

description:
My husband and I are huge fans of the fried rice.  Something about it is very addictive.  Lots of vegetables, lots of meat/tofu, they don't skimp on anything!  Worth it just to get the rice on a lunch break.  The curries are always good, especially the vegetable ones (again, they don't skimp! You get what you pay for), and the soups are wonderful!  Especially the tom yum - perfect sour savoriness.  Also, when it's available, the pumpkin curry is amazing!  And of course the iced tea.  It's a very mellow environment inside the restaurant within the bustling Castro... it's upstairs, so it's quiet, and the mood and the people are nice.  They were thoughtful to me when I came in to get takeout while carrying a baby - one of the chefs or waiters came from the back to help me get the food safely in my backpack since I was struggling with balancing my sleeping baby.  VERY thoughtful (I left a big tip!).  They sometimes decorate for holidays (I saw cool spiderwebs and fake spiders for Halloween, and I think lights during Christmas), which is fun.

The food is expensive, but what do you expect?  It's the Castro, and it's awesome Thai food, and it's totally worth it!
author: Yvea E.

description:
After an evening out in Castro my wife and I ended up here. It's been a while since our visit, but from what I can remember the food was good and cheap and the service was quick (no wait on a weekend night). Plus they were open late - another big plus.

The only downside that I can remember was that they didn't have a full liquor license: We were in the mood for cocktails but they could only serve  beer or wine. :(
author: Antti K.

description:
REMODELING DISASTER!!!!!

I've gone to this restaurant 4-5 times and I recently went for lunch.  I had a hard time concentrating on the food because of the interior of the restaurant.

The restaurant has been changed from a cozy, softly lit place great for a little intimate dinner into a sort of retro-70s futuristic cafeteria-in-the-asylum-for-the-criminally-insane look.  It's HORRIBLE.

Everything is white white white bright white -- the walls, the chairs, etc.  I've never been in a restaurant where the interior distracted me so from the dining experience.

If you like eating and feeling like you're sitting under klieg lights, go here.

UPDATE: I also went here for dinner.  For dinner the restaurant actually looks pretty cool.  DO NOT go here in the daytime unless you want go insane.  Maybe the restaurant was taken over by a vampire?

UPDATE2: The awful sheer whiteness has been softened by some purple, no longer burning out your retina while you dine there, I'm adding one star.
author: Eric v.

description:
Alright Thai food and an easy-to-spot location on Castro.  The two-person tables against the window are lovely if you can snag them; if not, erm, you can sit in the middle of things and listen to your neighbors' conversations--the tables are ridiculously close together.  I agree with the Amy E. who said the dining area is "dark but not romantically so"; much more "dark so watch out so as not to trip over a chair."  (No, I didn't trip; just stumbled. Oof.)

I tried a bit of my partner's pad thai and found it too sweet.  My pad see ewe was less sweet, but still less spicy than I would have preferred.  Most of the appetizers weren't available (on a Friday night?  Really?  We don't ask for incredibly bizarre things, I promise ...) but the fried spring rolls were alright.  Meh.  Pretty lukewarm experience overall.
author: Christina C.

description:
Meager. Timid. Overpriced. 

I figured Thai food wouldn't be hard to mess up...until I visited Thailand Restaurant in the Castro (2nd floor).Don't get me wrong- cool spot, great people, but they just don't know how to make Thai food. 

I took my parents to Muir woods for a walk in the rain. They got soaked. I figured they could use some hot and spicy soup to warm up their sensitive souls. Thai food should be the perfect remedy for a cold wintry SF day right? Not at this place. 

Tom Yum soup was lukewarm. Their ultra spicy was a mild tingling on my tongue. Instead of the pleasant lemongrass flavor, my stomach was upset from cheap vinegary sauce. All the veges in the soup is from canned goods. 

The Good:
* Good location
* Lunch menu

The Bad:
* Jasmine rice was not well cooked. 
* Pad Thai was too sweet...did I taste some ketchup. 
* Expensive relative to other Thai places. 

The Ugly:
* lack of authenticity
* lack of flavor
* overcharge on everything

Bottom line is: save your money, if you're vegetarian, this place only has so so tofu, no organic fresh veges. Try another place.
author: Jack C.

description: There are many thai restaurants in the city, most  of them are fancier than this one. But I really like this one because it offers a good mix of pretty good food, reasonable prices, and very friendly staff.  The location is great, yet it's less busy than other places in the castro, maybe because it's on the second floor? The lunch combo is a really good deal.
author: G Y.

description:
I'm updating a previous post - I've downgraded from three to one star  The place is dirty - we were grossed out after reviewing the results of their health inspection.  We hope they clean up.  If so, we'll return to the Spicy Tofu Fried Rice that we miss so much.

----------
My previous post from Nov '07:

One of my favorite Thai places in SF.  It's not the best Thai in SF, but the dishes that we favor are reliable and tasty.  

Their Spicy Tofu Fried Rice is a favorite, as is the Peanut Sauce Chicken.  The curries are acceptable.  The vegetable curry puffs are nice.  Some dishes haven't scored so high - we had a fried fish dish last night which wasn't so good.  The Tom Yum soup is good and the Pad Thai is as good as any.

The setting itself is not anything to write home about.  They have a lovely little Thai hut where the cash register is, but the rest of the place is painted in a not so appetizing purple with some beautiful accessories and some hideous.

The service has always been fine for us.  Once we were there and saw a couple walk out - we were wondering if there was some bug or roach near them, since they were looking around on the floor and on the wall - like they were looking to see where it went.  But we didn't see anything ourselves.

All in all, I can't give it higher than three stars, but we like the Tofu Fried Rice and the Peanut Sauce chicken well enough to keep coming back again and again, either for take out or sit down.
author: Bill V.

description: Not bad but lack of spices like a real Thai restaurant, it made for white people.
author: Cyprus N.

description: At lunch today, Pad Thai with fresh crab OMG! Really well!
author: Lee S.

description:
My boyfriend love to drive across the bay to this place. It is one of our favorites. The food is good and the service is great. All that work there are efficient and remember us from our last visit. We have even told them it was our Anniversary and they bring something out for us free of charge. How often does that happen in a Restaurant anymore?
They even have a big back room for parties. We have had parties there and they always turn out wonderful.
author: Mikey M.

description:
They remodeled. It looks FABULOUS. The food is good as always. Lots of great vegi choices. 

Now cuter on the inside that Thai Express Castro!
author: n s.

description:
Nothing in the Castro could be described as subtle, but even so I felt gratified indulging in this quiet symphony of flavor. 

I was very impressed with this place, mainly because of the value of it. 

The place is decorated in a sort of modern style with some unusual textures on the plates and walls. Derek Zoolander would be a regular here. 

The duck was well prepared and I was not let down by the ever impressive Thai curry. 

The service is prompt, however very aloof and mechanical. This is not a powerful negative, but it is something to take into account before setting an atmosphere. 

Verdict: Excellent value, good food, interesting atmosphere and lighting.
author: Jay C.

description: This is a really great lunch spot.  The food is great, lunch special is cheap and good.  I really enjoy the potato curry puffs, the eggrolls and panang curry with tofu.  For $7 you get a ton of food.  The location is perfect.  2nd floor and look out over Castro street with a great view of the theater.  So far I have not found better Thai food in the castro.
author: Jonathan U.

description: I usually have gone to Thai House Express for thai in the castro but my friend introduced me to Thailand Restaurant yesterday. We ate lunch there. We both had the pad see ew. It was very tasty and well priced - $6.95. The portion wasn't as huge as some, but I could still barely finish it. I liked the upstairs feel too. I will definitely come here again. The only thing that put me off was the sign outside - it looked kind of dated - but the inside is actually very nice and modern looking. Another good discovery.
author: Shannon R.

description:
I used to go here all the time.....until I went to cleanscores.com

EEK.

http://cleanscores.com/1699/
author: Jesse M.

description: picture perfect pretty presentation...pricing per petite plated portions par...tasting of high sweet and high salty...strong overpowering of saucing and seasoning....begging for more thai spice heat....sure...pad thai standard and acceptable...sauteed meats slighty overseasoned masked in saucing...roast duck to red, yellow and green curries...typical standard americanized sweet and saucy "authentic" thai...spicy non-spicy...dishes and tastes un-memorable...but, plenty of empty seating for last minute dinners for small or large....
author: Hen A.

description: Just concluded a lunch at this unpretentious Thai restaurant located on Casto Street in San Francisco. The meal was delicious and it was a great deal, especially considering the neighborhood. I highly recommend it (especially the green curry) to anyone.
author: Zachary L.

description: We are weekly customer at this restaurant. I have not yet experienced better or more fresh Thai food. Every dish is artful in presentation and delicious - hot and tasty. The pumpkin curry comes served inside its gourd bowl and the Coconut soups are to DIE for.
author: Melody M.

description: The food here is solid yummy.  The wait staff are awesome friendly and attentive.  I liked the decor better before they remodeled a few years ago.  It's a little cold now.  They could warm it back up by adding a bunch of plants.  That would push it back to five stars.
author: Napoleon R.

description:
I forget the exact name of what I ordered, but it was a spicy seafood (shrimp, scallops, squid) dish with wide noodles, basil leaves, and vegetables. The dish would have been better without the iceberg lettuce and under-ripe tomatoes. The staff was friendly and the menu was reasonably priced, but I am confident there are much better Thai restaurants in the area, and I will keep looking. 

In a word Thailand Restaurant was unimpressive.
author: Megan M.

description:
My favorite Thai resutrant of all time.  Been giong here since 1992 when we referred to it as The King and have never had a bad experience.  Maybe I'm missing something, but why hasn't anyone yelped this place? hmmmm

This is the place that made me fall in love with Thai Food and my appreciation of Elephants.

Pad Thai Talay, to die for.
author: Moira K.

description:
All right, I was really hoping that this place would be better. I was honestly a bit disappointed as I got lured into the place by newspaper articles gracing the side of the entrance to the restaurant (one needs to walk up the stairs to 2nd floor to reach it). The newspaper articles showcased Leon Lai (Lai Ming) and Maggie (both are Hong Kong famous movie stars/singers) dining at the place while visiting SF. Upon reaching the 2nd floor, there was a host that greeted me and seated me to a table with a view of the Castro Theater.

Customer Service: I sat down by myself and received the menu fairly quickly. I would say the customer service here was 3.5 stars. It wasn't great, but at least they were timely and came to refill my water once. They also got my bill/check out fairly quickly after I asked for it and were attentive enough to recognize that I was ready to order. However, the waiters were not necessarily extra nice by any means.

Food: I am a big fan of duck and ordered the roasted duck in red curry ($9.95). Rice (white) was ordered separately for an extra dollar. When I got both items, i was a bit shocked that the portions were a bit small (even for Castro standards cmon!!!). The scoop of rice was less than the size of my palm (very small indeed) and came in a little soap dish holder size rice plate. The duck curry came in a long dish, but very few pieces of duck and 4 pieces of pineapple. I have to give credit to the place for their saucing as it was pretty good- not too salty or spicy. It suited my taste buds well, but I was very VERY disappointed in the duck. I probably got a total of 5 actual pieces of duck and even within those pieces (about 2 inches long and 1/2 inch wide), half of it was seriously fat. Cmon now! I've never had duck in the bay area with that much fat. The duck wasn't very lean. True, sauce was great, but fatty duck doesn't make a girl happy. Then came the dessert I ordered because I wasn't full off the 5 pieces of duck and 4 pineapple slices. I ordered the roti (think Southeast Asian style "bread"/fried with condensed milk) for $3.00. I got it with the condensed milk on top of the "bread". I thought it was okay though it's hard to go wrong by pouring condense milk onto something like fried "bread". All together, my meal totaled $18.00 including a 15% ish tip. 

Ambiance: Credit for the restaurant for keeping part of the Victorian style facade and for not over decorating. During half way through my dinner, the waiter came by and placed a light candle on my table. I guess that was the centerpiece for later dinner times (I ate around 7:15pm) or so.  

Parking: Good luck. Street meters only. paid parking on weekdays and before 6pm. Weekends after 6pm and Sunday (all day) are free. I would suggest using public transit.

Transit: Take BART and get off at any stop in downtown SF (my suggestion would be embaracaero bart station. Then ride/board a MUNI lightrail and get off at 

Payment: Takes VISA and Mastercard, but with min. 10 dollar purchase. Cash only otherwise.
author: Tina C.

description: i have lived in san francisco for 13 and have been soming to Thailand Restaurant ever since i moved here.   i just read a terrible review of the place and am appalled.   i have never had a bad experience here, have always been greeted well, treated well, and never demanded of anything.  The food is great and i keep coming back.   And i don't even live in the neighborhood.
author: Mike F.

description:
I've been coming to this restaurant for years and have always enjoyed the homey decor, large servings of decent food and good service.  
Well, times have changed the old place.
The new decor is a disaster.  Welcome to the '80s.  The uncomfortable, charmless part of the '80s.  The food on my last visit was not very good.
Chewy pad thai and a bland fish curry.  The servings of rice are quite small (what ever happened to the traditional decorative aluminum serving bowl?).  The prices have gone up and our usual $24 dinner for two now rang in at $40!  Finally, what have they done with the portraits of the King and Queen? (A requisite fixture in ALL Thai restaurants)
Too bad, this used to be one of the Castro's little gems.
author: Colin M.

description: We only went here because Thai House Express was closed last Sunday night (due to no hot water or something).  I was pleasantly surprised.  The prices are good and the food very tasty.  A little smaller portions than some Thai places, but that isn't really a bad thing.  I think this is our new "go to" Thai place in the Castro.
author: Bob C.

description:
My husband & I love the food in the Castro District (and here is another one!) 
We were promptly seated in a nice section by a window overlooking the street below. We placed our order I got the lunch combo of chicken satay along with mixed veggies. We ordered a sampler appetizer dish. I liked them all but really didn't care for the fish patty thing. My husband got the green curry and some beef dish. The dishes they bring the food out to you are huge and they serve it with a side of peanut sauce and a cucumber/onion mix and a big pile of jasmine rice. All real good. 
They do keep an eye on your water levels, they must have refilled my water at least 4 times! I never had to ask for a refill (that's a plus) 
Maybe they should use bigger glasses - lol 
This place has some good food (only wished it was closer to home) its gotta be authentic, if you take a look at your bill you'll notice its written in Thai.
author: Sandy N.

description: My boss at my previous job took all his employees to dinner here on a regular basis.  Service is always friendly and pretty quick even during their busiest hours.  Favorite items here are the tom kha kai (chicken coconut soup) and pad se ew.
author: Michelle N.

description: I've been back once since they're done the remodel. Looks like my theory runs true.  No longer purple, no longer as good and the prices have increased.
author: Yan E.

description: I love this restaurant and come here often.  Delivery is also very fast and always accurate.  I get their Pad See Ew and it's amazing.  Their prawn and vegetable tempura is also great.  This is by far the best Thai restaurant I have found in the Castro, Duboce Triangle and Lower Haight area.
author: M H.

description: This place has consistently been one of my favorite restaurants for over 10 years! It is sooo good! Love the gai ga praw, pra ram, tom ka gai, the list goes on & on! Also, they have gotten well informed about gluten here lately, and you can order many things without gluten or soy sauce... Yay!
author: laura g.

description:
good food, good service, good price, fun location. good view.

last time i was there, i had:
duck curry
chicken satay
author: Greg D.

description: There are Thai restaurants a-plenty in San Francisco and the Castro has more than its fair share. Given the price point and generally decent service the mediocre food becomes bearable. Take away one of those items and honestly, why bother going. So is the case with Thailand Restaurant. There is nothing wrong with the food, for the most part it tastes like the food from the other two Thai restaurants located a block away. The service however is maddening. After getting seated it took about 10 minutes for someone to approach us about drinks and food. We ordered everything at once and everything came piece meal (if at all). Some people got all their food at once. Others got an appetizer and then nothing. One person ordered a salad, got their food 10 minutes after the last hot dish was brought to the table - but only after hounding the entire staff multiple times about the missing dish. Needless to say we ate our food cold. We were ready to pay and be gone before we were even done eating. Only the bill never came. We had to run after a server for the bill. Then we had to bring it to the cashier ourselves. Then we had to do the math for them. We noticed 2-3 other tables around us experienced the same issues. I think i did potential patrons a favor by turning their Open sign to Closed.
author: Ray C.

description: Don't understand why there are only three stars. Food is really good and authentic here. I highly recommend Thai omelet with minced chicken or pork (btw, it is not on the menu). Thai BBQ beef, yellow curry with chicken, eggplant with basil are really tasty. Sometimes, it can be kinda noisy. In general, staffs are nice and service is quick. High recommended.
author: Alex L.

description: I have a love for Thai food, and this place was decent.  It wasn't excellent, but it had pretty good tasty classic dishes.  The price was very reasonable for the portions served, and the service wasn't too bad.  The ambiance of the restaurant was nice for the dinner I was there for.
author: Nancy C.

description: I came here on Saturday night before catching a movie at the Castro Theater, and the second I opened the front door it dawned on me that this is the first place I've ever eaten Thai food! I came to SF on a trip in high school in 2001 and our chaperone brought us here. I remember thinking the pad thai was delicious, and I wish I'd ordered it this weekend because the green curry was pretty much what you might expect at a Thai restaurant. Green curry is green curry, right? I'm glad I found this place. I'll definitely be going back soon to check up on the pad thai and I'll update then.
author: Amy Z.

description: Had lunch there today. The food was very impressive! Some of the best Pad Thai I've had. The lunch special was an amazing deal and the atmosphere was really nice. Definitely great quality...maybe even deserves 5 stars, but I usually save that for my top very very favorite restaurants. Highly recommend it and will be back!
author: Jason G.

description: Conveniently located in the Castro but inside it's eclectic -- which is code for tacky decor. The bright neon lights from outside illuminate the main dining room giving a feel of vegas strip or a eating in cheap motel. But don't let that discourage you for the very safe and ordinary Thai food you can find here. Many dishes are around $9 for dinner....
author: Eric M.

description:
This used to be our favorite place for Thai, both dine-in or delivery.  Last Saturday (02/27/10), three of us had dinner, ordering family-style.  However, only I ate some of one dish (Seafood Clay Pot).   As we paid the bill, I began to feel a bit unwell.  Arriving home (Noe Valley) I felt increasing nauseous .   Within 5 minutes I was violently ill.  Immediately I felt fine.  

The next evening I returned, with the leftovers.  I related the events to the hostess and 2 male staff (owners, perhaps).  Far from being apologetic, they were clearly skeptical and even hostile.   Caveat emptor.
author: duke k.

description: Worst Thai place I have been to in the city so far.  The food was watered down and me and my bf sat their and looked at each other and laughed when the power wen off!! LOL....this was suppose to be our anniversary dinner but turned out to me an adventure.   That's all I can say about that lol
author: Rob P.

description: Ordered delivery from here on a rainy Sunday, a shrimp dish and Tom Kah Gai - both were terrible. The Tom Kah Gai was coconut milk with button mushrooms and too-chewy chicken, barely any spice. Throwing out this delivery menu immediately.
author: Casey W.

description:
gross. I've only been here once and was only impressed by the decor - i wish i could say the same about the food. Thankfully I ate before or I would have starved! i ordered the lunch combo soup+ 2 entrees + salad for 9 bucks.  That should have sent red flags like crazy so i blame myself.  First the soup was watered down and with a funky super sweet taste? like they were making up the flavor with some sugar and chili pepper. I have had this type of tofu soup before so I knew the taste was very off. then the lunch combo came i had the chicken satay and a veggies w tofu.  The "salad" was 4 pieces of iceberg lettuce with hidden ranch.  f. my life. the veggies and tofu was actually quite good but it was about 1 cup worth of food.  the satay chicken was dry and not marinated nor thick  to the standards of other places. ugh.  I wanted to like this place because the location and decor are great but it comes down to the food for me. i would rather eat in a basement in Soma and  have good food than here.

or walk down to the mission and get a taco
author: Paola L.

description:
rumor has it many kung fu flicks were filmed here.
have I seen one? no...
why they would film in a Thai restaurant I dunno...
maybe it's the food?
or the service?
it's all pretty good here.
author: Matt V.

description: A hidden gem really. I always walk past the sign to this place and have always been intrigued. After a great show of The sound of music sing-a-long at Castro theater, we were hungry and decided to try this place. As we go up the stairs, the place is nice and clean. We are seated immediately and get a view of the castro sitting near the window! Sweet! The food was good, too! Spicy and flavorful. We had noodle dishes with shrimp...yum! The service is prompt and the staff are courteous! I will definitely come back to this place!!!!
author: Mel P.

description: I wish they would un-remodel the place back to way it was. I would give it five stars back then. The food is still good and the views are great. If you get a window seat it has a beautiful view of the Castro Theatre!! Be sure to have the tufo and spinach dish.
author: David P.

description: Good ole reliable standby in fun second-floor street-gazing location (ask for a window table).  Pad kee mao goong -- chili-basil noodles with shrimp is quite good as are the fish cakes appetizer and the typical yellow curry with chicken and potatoes.  Nothing amazing here but have not had anything terrible either.  Good deal for lunch specials -- my friend Alberto and I used to eat here a lot for Saturday or Sunday lunch while out shopping and running errands.  The service is pretty good and the place is fairly quiet and above the fray that is Castro Street on the weekends.  If you use the loo, mind the gap or rather mind the step -- both when entering and exiting.  Almost took an embarrassing pratfall last night.
author: Xander S.

description: Ended up eating here because we were too lazy to wait 45 minutes for a table at Thai House Express (especially when their same menu is available at the Tenderloin Thai House with never a wait). Our window seat gave us a view over Castro, which was fun. My green bean tofu dish (I forget the name, you know the one every place serves) tasted good but left a thick coating of bright orange oil all over my plate. I didn't much like the pink walls and heard too many details of our neighbors' conversation, plus it was kind of dark and not romantically so.
author: Amy E.

description: My friend and I went there early for dinner, so we got prime people-watching seating by the windows. Later another party was seated at the table next to us and it was a little awkward because we were quite close to each other. The food was good-great, very reasonable prices. I loved my friend's food better than mine though-she got the chicken dish with the rice noodles. It was perfect. I always try pad thai at thai restaurants to see how they prepare the most common standard thai dish. While it was good, I think they added too much of the sweet sauce and noodles. Lots of noodles, a little clumped together and more than the chicken with the noodles. Hmmm, I don't remember tasting the peanut sauce. It was decent, but  at this price, it was something I could swallow for sure.
author: Jenny W.

description: Perfectly tasty Thai food with festive (read: colorful) decor and lots of vegetarian options. They'd get an extra star if rice was included with the entrees and if they delivered to my 'hood. HAYES VALLEY HATERS!
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
this used to be my favorite favorite go-to thai restaurant. i've just become a lot lazier since moving further away from here, but this place is definitely one of my top 3 fav thai restaurants in SF. 

the service is amazing. the waiter tries to remember my and my friend's names bc we came here so often (i think he only remembers my friend's ---darn you generic vietnamese name, feels like high school).

the food is above average. always fresh, warm, and nicely presented. i love love love the the tom yum soup here. 

another great plus is the ambiance. i love entering through the steps from below and getting a seat near the window to see the bustling streets of castro -- so aim for one of those if you can!
author: Amanda N.

description: the service here is impecible!!!  They sat us quickly, served us quick, asked if i needed more, a refill, if we liked the food... I was very impressed!!  The vegetarian green curry with tofu is fantastic!!!!  I am usually very hard to please because I want spicy.. BUT I am so white people think I can't take it.  Well, I can take it.  If you read my other reviews you will note that I need snot running out of my nose and lots o water.. this place gave me what I was looking for!  woohoo for sniffles galore!!!  They also had a vege tom kha soup!!!  THE BEST I HAVE EVER HAD!!  to die for!!!!  affordable, clean, quick, great view upstairs looking down on the castro... can't wait to go back!!
author: blair k.

description:
really good, though not the greatest thai food around.  

thailand restaurant gets four stars because:
* they don't skimp on tofu (sooo many thai places do)
* the food is pretty damn good.  i love the vegetarian spring rolls.
* THEY DELIVER!  (seriously, a huge plus for a really good restaurant).

placing an order over the phone can be tough.  just be patient and make sure they repeat the order back to you.  they always get my order right in the end.
author: Karen R.

description: My partner and I went Saturday night about 7pm, it was deserted but soon got busy cause I think the movie let out next door.  We had 2 appitizers that were only OK, then the entrees came and he was about to send it back because he ordered the duck and all that came for him was an oval bowl of vegetables.  We poked the veggies aside and viola! a few chuncks of dark meat which was the duck.  It was like the old story of the fancy restaurant and the guy orders a steak and his plate comes but there is no steak so he moves a few peas and there is the steak.  Seriously.   My beef entree was good and served with a scoop of rice. Also a 7-up=$47.  Too much for too little and the food was mediocre.  Nice view window table tho.  Won't be back, too many other better places.
author: William G.

description: I had a bad experience here. The atmosphere (looking over castro street) is nice, but the food wasn't very good. The pad see ew was slimy and lacked flavor. The yellow curry wasn't yellow, (red/brown) and didn't taste like curry. It wasn't cheap, though not expensive either, and left me wondering why the lack of quality? It confounded me given the other quality thai places in the city. I'm not going back.
author: Micah R.

description: I used to come here every so often to have a scrumptious yet inexpensive meal with some friends and I would've given it 5 stars. But, I've returned twice ever since they remodeled and I would have to dock 2 stars out for the decor. Food and service were still awesome but the new look just didn't do it for me. It definitely lost much of it's old charm.
author: Charles U.

description:
I had dinner in that restaurant 3 nights in a row and had the yellow curry and each time it appears to become less appetizing.

I honestly started my yelp account because i was so upset at the poor level of service i got. The curry was swimming in oil, like a lost tanker. I politely explain to the young lady who was acting as host who then, told me "that how it was it made and i had it last time". I ask her to take it way and she asks if i want it boxed to go. Seriously~

I even had to write it on the back of my card receipt how annoyed i was. That's the last time my and my folks will venture to that place.

P.S food at any restaurant can be bad, it the service and how mistakes are taken care of that really keeps me going to some restaurants.
author: dolce c.

description: It's a shame they deserve only one star. I admit, the food is pretty good there, but it's the service that upset me. I found a long piece of hair in my water. It was disgusting. I was speechless, how could the waitress miss that (And I'm pretty sure it was her hair) ? I brought back the glass to her, told her what I found, and she just said "I'll get you another one". Not a single word of apology. On top of that, during the service, she slammed down the dishes, and drinks down on my table. No respect for the customer at all.
author: Jelly G.

description:
my friends and i are obsessed with this place. back in the spring (around the time they remodeled), it broke our hearts that they were closed for a couple of weeks. i get cravings for the food here.

i love the cashew nut chicken. but like any thai place, avoid those dark, mysterious peppers - they are extremely spicy. the panang curry is also delicious. the ambience has changed since the remodeling, but the food is still just as tasty. 
once while my friends and i were there late one evening, the waiter kindly asked if we'd be able to switch tables to make space for a larger party. we were completely fine moving, but they still gave us thai iced tea on the house. yum! the wait staff is very friendly as well.
author: Dina S.

description: wow. we ordered delivery of a bunch of vegetarian dishes including the eggplant, spinach, tofu salad, and pad thai. sides of peanut sauce, cucumber salad, and brown rice. very clean tasting food - really not too greasy at all. food arrived in good time and was hot. reasonably priced - $68 incl. tip fed 4 of us very well with leftovers. will definitely order from here again.
author: Rossa S.

description:
We ordered mango salad (day's special), pad thai and yellow chicken curry.  They all had good flavor, but noodle lumped together and potato in curry was undercooked.  

Ambiance was good, but it was a little too dark to appreciate colors of our food.  It got a little noisy when more people arrived, as sound echoed well within the large room.

Price was very reasonable.
author: April H.

description:
My Partner and I stopped by after a movie on Saturday night. We have seen this place for years and decided to try it. What a mistake! There food is a poor excuse for Thai food and it is very overpriced. We ordered two appetizers; the Thai rolls and chicken satay before our entree. The Thai rolls were so hard and overcooked as to be unpleasant and we never received the satay. Our entrees were equally unimpressive and the pad Thai actually was bad. The wait staff was equally unimpressive, poor communication skills, brought the wrong wine twice, forgot our appetizers, and it took sooo long to get our food. 

When we asked for the check they asked about our food and we were very pleasant, but honest. She looked at us, said nothing and walked away. OK, so the check comes and the satay we never received is on the bill. So we explained we never received the satay and they immediately said OK and took the check back. When the check came back to the table the satay and price were whited out, but she did not change the total bill...HELLO. After discussing it with two other waiters and asking for a calculator, they adjusted our bill correctly. Never again, it is amazing such a restaurant can stay in business. Pass this one by and find one of the other good Thai places in the Castro.
author: Jeff H.

description: Last Friday evening I had the pleasure of meeting up with a friend and dining at this establishment. Since my last visit quite a number of years ago, there has been some really eye-popping remodeling to the space, bringing it up to a more mod look. My friend ordered a cup of the tom ka gai soup (chicken coconut soup) and basil chicken, while I had the yum pla muk (calamari salad) and veggie raad na pak (flat noodles with tofu, broccoli, and a light gravy). My friend was in heaven with his selections. I have always enjoyed the piquant flavor combos in Thai salads, and this calamari dish was no exception--I love all the basic flavors of sweet, spicy, and sour coming through in that salad, as well as the perfectly blanched calamari. The raad na, however, had a disappointingly simple flavor profile and a bit off-putting texture in the gravy. Not sure what happened with the starches or other components in that dish. Other than that, I enjoyed the meal with a Singha(tm) beer and the company. And yes, I probably will return to try other dishes here.
author: Ryan T.

description: Average thai experience. The menu was exhaustive, and the prices very reasonable. This could have been four stars, but felt that my chicken/eggplant dish was lacking in chicken, and the bean sauce seemed really, really oily. I did appreciate that there to go container was microwavable, and recyclable.
author: Jason B.

description: My favorite thai- decor went from one extreme( dark, purple, tacky) to another  ( sleek, hi-tech ) but the food is well priced and fabulous. The hostess /manager /Mum, holds it together with great style, humor and a winning smile. We love this place!
author: Philip R.

description: I just spent three months traveling in Thailand, and the food here was great!  I especially loved the Panang curry with vegetables.  The servers were all very friendly and helpful, and accommodated us by bringing us something different when we misordered.  The vegetables were fresh and cooked well; the flavors went together perfectly; they have brown rice; and the presentation was great.  I would definitely go back!  Go for the nice table by the windows for a nice view of Castro.
author: Melissa M.

description: I've enjoyed eating at Thailand Restaurant for over 15 years now.  However, while the food is still good, tonight I went there for the first time in quite a while and was terribly disappointed to discover that their recent attempt at "remodeling" has created a place where you have to scream and yell to be heard by the waiter and dinner companions.  This place used to have good sound-deadening, but no more.  Now it's an extremely loud place and I won't be going there again.  They lost a long-time, loyal customer.
author: Tony D.

description: i end up here every couple of months, when my boyfriend decides he doesn't want to tip out to Clement Street and go to King of Thai.  you gotta love the lilac walls and the cobwebs trailing from the feet of the carved wood celestial orchestra figures. you gotta really love the chips atop the salad kak. you gotta really really love the requisite portraits of the ruling couple of Thailand and join me, won't you, in wondering why there are lame old jalapeno peppers in one of the condiment containers ... condiments, mind you, that one has to request and condiments, mind you again, that do not include ground peanuts or sugar.  but they do have that soft shell crab in peanut curry sauce thing that delights me every time i eat it ... and it has the word poo in its name so i have to point at it instead of saying it out loud.
author: Kevin M.

description: My boyfriend remembered this place from visiting San Francisco about 6 years ago and was frothing at the bit to go there for dinner.  It was my first experience with Thai food beyond the usual Satay and Pad Thai.  I'd have to say that it was pretty excellent, the portions were huge and the food was flavorful.  The deep fried tofu was pretty awesome and a magnificent chicken curry dish served out of a pineapple.  This one isn't on the menu, so ask for it.
author: H. H.

description: I love this place.  The food is good and staff is wonderful.  For a Castro location, they are great with kids even though we seldomly see children here.    It's our son favorite restaurant.   We always end up ordering Fish cake, Basil chicken, Tom yum gai, and Pad thai.  But the comfort Thai dishes here hit the spot.
author: David B.

description: I had dinner last night with a friend at Thailand Restaurant.  I had not been in a few years, but it still continues to be a solid choice for Thai.  We ordered to share which included chicken satay, basil shrimp and green curry chicken over rice.  Everything had really even, nice flavors.  I certainly wasn't blown away, but I enjoyed the food, service and calming atmosphere.  I also like the fact that you are on the second floor with a direct view of the Castro theater.  I recommend for solid, reasonably priced Thai food in the Castro.
author: Erin K.

description: J had been here before, and he did not like it. Since we have almost the same tastes, I never went there. Basically, of one of us tries something, we can tell if the other will like it. Then, recently, he had to go there for some reason, and he liked what he got. So we all ended up going, and I got to try it. The advice I was given was to try something that is NOT a curry. The first time, I tried some basil seafood thing. It was ok, nothing special. There is no sticky rice, just regular rice. The thai iced tea wasn't too good. we had some spring rolls which were tasty enough. Overall, it was ok, nothing great. Before I had a chance to yelp it, I went here again. the first time was a Saturday evening and we were seated right away. This time was after 9pm on a Thursday nite. They close at 10 but still seated us. This time I ordered what j always orders.  Just told the waitress, I'll have what he's having. It was a seafood thing with a red chile sauce... it was good. I liked it! The iced tea was better too. And, even though it was late, we weren't rushed out. b liked his soup too. My other roomie n likes this place too, so now that I know what I should order when I come here, its good, and I would come back again. so the moral of this story is, if you don't like this place the first time, give it a 2nd try. If you still don't like it, maybe you just don't like it.
author: Merredith L.

description: First let me start by saying that both my husband and I have lived in San Francisco for over 25 years but neither of us had ever been in this restaurant.  The evening with my visiting two nieces started pleasantly enough.  We got a table right away and our drink order came quickly.  Things went downhill rather rapidly after that.  The appetizer that came out of the kitchen was the wrong item.  When I told the waiter it was the wrong thing, he insisted that what I ordered was correct.  I told him no that was not what I ordered.  He took it back and he was clearly pissed at us.  The first entree arrived before the correct appetizer did.  The girls and I all ordered three different types of pad thai (one with chicken, one vegetarian, and one with shrimp) -- okay so we weren't creative that evening -- and my husband ordered his usual yellow curry.  Things did not arrive at the table consistently and while husband was waiting for his rice, the waiter came out to tell us there was no white rice available.  He could have brown rice at the same price of white rice.  The pad thai was "okay" but it was a gelatinous mess that the minute it hit the plate started to congeal. The yellow curry was not very tasty and was made mostly from the cheaper dark meat.  But in addition to the rude service -- I gave the waiter a 15% tip which I probably shouldn't have -- the revenge was in their favor.  I had terrible diarrhea last night as soon as we got home.  I would love to see what previous reviewers were referring to about the CleanScores.com reviews, but they all show 100.  Something must be off on this one.  Next time, we'll skip this tomain house and go to Thai House Express at 599 Castro.
author: Jeff S.

description: i remember having a nice early evening dinner here by the picture window, and had fun viewing all the people moving to & fro Castro Street.   i also enjoyed the interiors!
author: Jerome Espinosa B.

description:
I've been coming here for fifteen years.
Atmosphere:
I personally love atmosphere including new touches like the new transparent waterfall over the glass window (used to be a fishtank), and I enjoy the modern textured white tiles on the dining room wall.
The gem studded dragons and shrine to Thai leaders as you know are a bit irrelevant now that Thailand has undergone a sea change of civil unrest. I miss the quaintness, but appreciate the modern Gay Redo. It looks like it got hit by the Fab Five and  - hello - its in the Castro after all.
Finding the Yummy
 I notice one timers order lots and lots of the fried dishes. These diners leave with a lukewarm impression. Underneath the obligingly familiar "American Eggroll" taste for those "who get the same thing every time", are a selection of more Thati tasting more authentic dishes. Here are some suggestions:
Try the appetiser called "fresh rolls", similar to summer rolls in a Vietnamese or Cambodian restaurant-soft, unfried and yummy sauce to go with---these are new; or the fish cake appetizers. Very nicely seasoned. Yes, pan fried is not the same as deep fried in pastry - is it? If you must, order the chicken satay.
For a beverage I highly reccommend the cold Young Coconut or HOT Thai tea. Try it. 
Order a soup. Any soup. The coconut milk and lemongrass will make the entrees taste even better and get your digestive juices flowing. Just do it.
For an entree, I reccommend the clay pot entrees, or the lighter red, green or red curries. Any of the curry sauces are a delight. For much lighter fare, try the silver noodle (glass noodle) dishes. If you want to be adventurous, order Pad Thai and ask them to put extra shrimp paste in it!!!!!
Try these tips and you will uncover a lovely Thai restaurant in the gayest neighborhood in America and the best view of a great American moviehouse, the Castro Theatre.
author: Nan L.

description: I've come here for many years and I've had three meals here recently. The food was great each time, and the servers were very friendly. The prawn won ton appetizer (don't remember exactly what it was called) was delicious, as was the Tom Kha Gai on my last visit. I agree with those who don't like the "updated" decor. It's cold and not very charming. However, the food is still great and the prices are reasonable.
author: Nat M.

description: Their Pad Kee Mao (spicy noodle with chicken or pork), Gang Ped Yang (Roast Duck Red Curry), and Tom Yum Gai (Chicken spicy and sour soup are great!  Not too greasy.  Service is pretty fast and attentive.  A good place to go before heading to the movies across the street at the Castro Theatre.
author: Ellie K.

description: Barely edible.  Couldn't finish. Raisins in my pineapple fried rice.  Should have charged 1/2 of what they did (no kidding). Delivery driver tried to add 18% onto the delivery tab.  Avoid.
author: Gwen S.
